post.title: Datapoint for feature 14A and language wals_code_bqs

text:
Another language 
lacking velar consonants is Wutung (Sko; Sandaun, Papua New Guinea), a 
very close relative of the already-cited Dumo. This is mentioned in my 
PhD thesis on the language.

post.title: Absence of Common Consonants

text:
You cite Lillooet 
(Salish) as exemplifying a 'differentiated' system. But Lillooet uses 
its general purpose conjunction  múta7 for coordination of all 
constituents, including clauses and DPs. It also uses its clefti marker 
nilh to connect sequences of clauses, but nilh is not really a 
conjunction, but a subordinating predicate. On your criteria, I'd 
therfore say that Lilllooet uses an 'identical' strategy.

Henry Davis

post.title: Nominal and Verbal Conjunction

text:
Nisga'a and Gitksan  
are mutually intelligible, and form part of an Interior Tsimshianic 
dialect continuum. They have identical nominal semantics, yet they are 
given different values on the map here! In fact, the Nisga'a value is 
correct: articles in IT are unspecified for (in)definiteness, and there 
is no definite affix (the Gitksan value must be a misreading of Rigsby's
 grammar).

Henry Davis

post.title: Definite Articles

text:
Unfortunately, the 
entire Pacific NW section of this map is completely wrong. Wakashan and 
Salish languages, in particular, are *famous* for lacking predicative 
copulas (that is one of the bases of Swadesh's notorious claim that they
 lack lexical category distinctions altogether). No Salish or Wakashan 
language has a copula in nominal predicae constructions: this includes 
Lilooet, Squamish and Kalispel (Salish) and Heiltsuk, Kwak'wala, and 
Nuuchahnulth (Wakashan). This is a pretty egregious error and should be 
fixed as soon as possible.

Henry Davis

post.title: Zero Copula for Predicate Nominals

text:
What Henry Davis says 
is consistent with how I have Gitksan coded in my database.  The current
 coding is due to a programming error.

post.title: Definite Articles

text:
There's another 
Gitksan~Nisga'a mistake in here. As I commented earlier, these two 
languages are mutually intelligible ends of the Interior Tsimshianic 
dialect continuum: they are not going to differ in major typological 
features.

In fact, both languages have very strict VSOA order. I'm not sure where 
the 'no dominant order' value comes from for Gitksan, unless the 
compiler is treating  pre-predicative ergative clitics as full arguments
 (but in that case, French would count as SOV whenever object clitics 
showed up).

Henry Davis

post.title: Order of Subject and Verb

text:
No Tsimshianic language ever allows OV order; the Gitksan value is anomalous here.

Henry Davis

post.title: Order of Object and Verb

text: Wrong again on Gitksan: strictly VSOX.

post.title: Order of Object, Oblique, and Verb

text:
The datapoint for 
Squamish (Salish) is incorrect. Like all other Salish languages, 
Squamish is head-marking: objects are obligatory encoded as suffixes on 
the verb, but there are no case distinctions and dependent marking is 
limited to a distinction between obliques and non-obliques.

post.title: Locus of Marking in the Clause

text: More Salish mistakes. Squamish has no pharyngeals. Shuswap does. Did you mix up the two Kuipers grammars?

post.title: Presence of Uncommon Consonants

text:
Bella Coola has both an ejective lateral affricate and a lateral fricative, contrary to what you have on the map.

Henry Davis

post.title: Lateral Consonants

text:
Sora does not have 5-6 vowels but nine: i e ɛ ɨ ə ɑ u o ɔ, without phonemic length.
Ramamurti's Telugu-influenced analysis with length, stress, etc., does not match any
of the dialects he investigated.  Actually even Ramamurti's analysis can't be taken
to have fewer than nine vowels.

The nine-vowel analysis, with occasional variations in symbols, has been 
independently arrived at in published and unpublished works produced since 1962
by H. S. Biligiri, David Stampe, Stan Starosta, Bijoy Prasad Mahapatra, Raganayaki
Mahapatra, Arlene R. K. Zide, Khageswar Mahapatra, and Arun Ghosh.  Gregory D. S.
Anderson's report in his edited Munda Languages volume was a hurried replacement 
article based on very brief field work, but despite its uncertainties it is not
incompatible with the majority analysis.

Incidentally, the Sora New Testament of the Canadian Baptist Mission also
nine vowels written i I e ü ə ɑ u U o (based on Ramamurti, w/o length or stress),
where ü was Ramamurti's misunderstanding of Sweet's notion "mixed vowel", really ɨ.
The full Bible was published in the English alphabet, but except for writing ə and ɑ
both as a, it also distinguishes the nine vowels (though with many mistakes).   
A detailed description of Sora phonology and phonetics is in preparation by
Patricia Donegan, donegan@hawaii.edu.

post.title: Nominal and Verbal Conjunction

text:
The problem raised by 
Henry Davis is actually more general than the Pacific Northwest.  In his
 book Intransitive Predication, Stassen has a more fine-grained typology
 in which languages in the Pacific Northwest are coded as languages in 
which predicate nominals have verbal encoding, taking affixes that also 
occur on predicate verbs.  His typology also distinguishes languages 
which do not employ copulas but where predicate nominals do not take 
verbal encoding, which he classifies as nominal encoding.  When his more
 fine-grained typology was collapsed into two types for WALS, those with
 verbal encoding were, for complex historical reasons, classified with 
languages where a zero copula is impossible.  This applies to all 
languages with verbal encoding, not just those in the Pacific Northwest.
  Stassen now agrees that this is very misleading and is planning on 
producing a version of this map in a future online WALS that employs a 
more fine-grained typology, in which these languages with verbal 
encoding will be treated as a separate type.

post.title: Zero Copula for Predicate Nominals

text:
Here's a textual 
example of clausal coordination with múta7 in St'át'imcets/Lillooet from
 Lisa Matthewson's 2005 volume of personal histories of St'át'imc 
elders: (the example is in the van Eijk practical orthography in common 
use in Lillooet territory):

[xzum	ti=q’úmqen-s=a]		múta7 [xzum	   ti=tsútsin-s-a]
[big           det=head-3poss=exis]     and     [big           
det=head-3poss=exis]
"It's head was big and it's mouth was big."

The reason why múta7 is less common as a clausal conjunction than as a 
phrasal conjunction is because unlike English 'and' it never encodes 
temporal sequencing, so it is limited to cases like the one above where 
there is no temporal ordering between clauses. 

Henry Davis

post.title: Nominal and Verbal Conjunction

text:
There is a past tense. 
It is signaled by a tonal system. For example, with the simple past 
tense, the syllables of the verb clause remain constant until the last 
vowel (on the last syllable of the verb) , where this vowel is elongated
 and a downstep is applied to its tone. With the past participle, an 
up-step is applied to the beginning of the noun clause (on the first 
syllable of the noun). This might not be apparent to non-native 
speakers, but this tonal ( tone-terracing) system is very real. 
Sometimes the tone is applied to the vocal accompaniment to nasal 
consonants making it ever more undetectable for non-native speakers yet 
still existent and necessary communicating in the language.

These simple guidelines are just illustrative and their simplicity is 
their error because there is a highly complex system underlying the 
system, much like any language.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 66A and language wals_code_akn

text:
Concerning: No 
grammatical evidential in Mapudungun (you refer to Smeets 1989!!!). To 
the best of my knowledge, this claim is simply not true. In Smeets 
(1989, p. 322 ff.) it says quite clearly: ”[-(ü)rke] … indicates that 
the denoted situation has not been witnessed by the speaker himself. 
[It] indicates that the speaker is informed by others, has heard 
rumours, or has deduced a conclusion. Although the source of information
 is left unspecified, it is usually evident who the source of 
information is. I found [it] in indicative forms only. [It] is very 
frequent in narratives.”

In fact evidentiality or mediativity (plus mirativity) is mentioned in 
every handbook/grammar/descripition of the language by the specialist of
 the language, right from the beginning! How come you haven't consulted 
the relevant sources, before ruling out a category for a language.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 77A and language wals_code_map

text:
Although many authors 
describe the case markers in Basque as suffixes, they should be 
considered postpositional clitics in the light of the definition: ‘while
 they[=the adpositional clitics] attach phonologically to some word, the
 word they attach to need not be a noun, and which word they attach to 
is determined syntactically.’

The case markers in Basque do attach to a noun, an adjective or a 
determiner. In fact the word they are fixed to is the final one of noun 
phrases. See the examples below:

1) bost gizon=i
    five  man=DAT
    ‘to five men’
2) gizon haue=i
    man   these=DAT
    ‘to these men’
3) bost gizon gazte=ri
    five  man   young=DAT
    ‘to five young men’

The dative marker =(r)i is attached to a noun, a determiner, and an 
adjective in each sentence.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 104A and language wals_code_ika

text:
Data from Kabardian is 
misinterpreted due to the inadequacy of the source. There is a mistake 
in Colarusso's example on p. 106 (the object of an antipassive verb, if 
it is expressed at all in the first place, which is normally not the 
case, cannot appear in the Absolutive case). The situation with 
antipassives in Kabardian (and in the closely related Adyghe) is 
complex; see e.g. Smeets 1992, Kumakhov & Vamling (2006). Generally,
 antipassivization renders the verb monovalent, i.e. the original object
 can no longer be expressed at all. With some verbs the object can be 
expressed as an adjunct in the Instrumental case, and another couple of 
verbs have a bivalent antipassive with the original O expressed as a 
indirect object cross-referenced in the verb and marked with the Oblique
 case used for non-Absolutive arguments.

Reference:
Kumaxov, Muxadin A., Vamling, Karina. 2006. Ėrgativnost’ v čerkesskix 
jazykax. Malmö: Malmö University: School of International Migration and 
Ethnic Relations. 2006.
Smeets R. On valencies, actants and actant coding in Circassian. // G. 
Hewitt (ed.), Caucasian Perspectives. München, Newcastle: LINCOM Europa,
 1992, pp. 98—144.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 37A and language wals_code_bul

text:
The statement that 
copula deletion is impossible in Irish is wrong. Ó Siadhail 1989, which 
is referred to without page reference, actually has a section "Deletion 
of copula" (pp.244–5), at the outset of which the following statement is
 made:
"A very general rule which seems to apply to all dialects is that the 
copula form _is_ may be deleted at the beginning of an utterance. This 
can be stated negatively by saying that the copula may not normally be 
deleted when marked for mood, tense, negation, interrogation or when 
embedded in a sentence"
In fact, this statement of Ó Siadhail’s strikes me as very appropriate, 
and it is my own observation that this is accurate.
Therefore I suggest changing the value of the datapoint for Irish to 
"possible".

post.title: Datapoint for feature 51A and language wals_code_bsq

text:
Though I'm not a big 
fan of major constituent order as a meaningful typological category, I 
may as well point out that the Salish languages represented here are 
more uniform than the maps make them look. To be precise, all of them 
are V-initial, with flexible post-predicative order (VOS/VSO). In most 
languages/dialects (all of Central Salish, Lower Lillooet, Thompson, 
Okanagan), the 'unmarked' order (in sentences presented out of the blue 
containing two animate arguments) is VSO; in  some Interior languages 
(Upper Lillooet, Moses Columbia, Coeur D'Alene) it is VOS. Nearly all 
Salish languages also allow SVO under more or less restricted 
circumstances (more restricted in Central Salish, less so in the 
Interior). The only exception I know of is Bella Coola, which has  rigid
 VSO order without an SVO alternant. 
   However, Salish data points are spread across maps 81and 81b, falsely
 giving the impression, for example, that Lillooet differs fundamentally
 from Shuswap and Thompson, its closest relatives. As often, this is a 
problem with sources, which exaggerates cross-linguistic differences: 
van Eijk (1997) simply didn't have enough data to characterize word 
order accurately, given the paucity of sentences with two overt 
arguments in the  traditional narratives which formed the empirical 
basis of his grammar.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 44A and language wals_code_mnd

text:
The Finnish data 
illustrate one of the problems encountered when relying on dictionary 
data: dictionaries might actually be used to inform the user of 
differences. Hence, if one were to query the Finnish-language word 
"käsi" in a Finnish-English word list, it would be found that the single
 word "käsi" is translated into English as either 'hand' or 'arm'. If on
 the contrary a English-Finnish word list were consulted, the Finns 
would probably differentiate in the Finnish glosses. After 
differentiation the English word "hand" would be glossed 'käsi' and 
"arm" would be glossed 'käsivarsi'. The same dictionary, if the first 
half is Finnish-English and the second half is English-Finnish, which is
 probably the case with Aino Wuolle's dictionary, will attest to both 
"distinction" and "no distinction".
I hope that you are able to change the WALS map values.
Finnish should be in the same group as Northern Sámi where "giehta" 
means both 'hand' and 'arm'.
Estonian "käsi" also means both 'hand' and 'arm'.
Erzya "кедь" also means both 'hand' and 'arm'.
Sincerely,
Jack Rueter, PhD

You have Nisga'a down

'weakly suffixing'). This is misleading/wrong; Nisga'a has suffixes for 
for one entire pronominal paradigm (which marks subjects, objects, and 
possessors), and a variety of strategies for plural marking, including 
prefixation and suffixation, as well as reduplication and suppletion. 
There is certainly more inflectional morphology in Nisga'a than in 
English, which you list as 'strongly suffixing'.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 38A and language wals_code_jpn

text:
The Hopi front rounded 
vowel is probably more accurately described as a low vowel. In the Hopi 
Dictionary (Hill, et al 1998) it is transcribed as [ɶ] rather than [ø] 
or [œ] (p 863).

A neighboring Uto-Aztecan language, Ute, has a genuine mid front rounded
 vowel /ø/ (Oberly 2008, pp 93-4, Givón 2011, p 18). It corresponds to 
Southern Paiute /ɔ/ (Sapir 1930, p 302). (ISO 639-3 doesn't distinguish 
between Southern Paiute and Ute and labels both languages as "ute".)

References:
* Givón, T. 2011. Ute Reference Grammar. John Benjamins Publishing 
Company.
* Hill, K., E. Malotki, M. Black, and the Hopi Dictionary Project. 1998.
 Hopi Dictionary/Hopìikwa Lavàytutuveni: A Hopi-English Dictionary of 
the Third Mesa Dialect. University of Arizona Press.
* Oberly, S. 2008. A Phonetic Analysis of Southern Ute with a Discussion
 of Southern Ute Language Policies and Revitalization. PhD dissertation,
 University of Arizona, Tucson.
* Sapir, E. 1930. Text of the Kaibab Paiutes and Uintah Utes. 
Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, vol 65 No 2.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 60A and language wals_code_jpn

text:
In modern Greek, it is 
the same word (χέρι, akin to ancient Greek χείρ as in chiropractor) that
 is used for both "hand" and "arm".  Now, a separate word for "arm" does
 exist (μπράτσο, from Italian "braccio", akin to English "brace") but 
nonetheless, χέρι can mean either hand or arm.  In fact, misuse of hand 
in place of arm is a common mistake among Greek learners of English.  
So, I believe that modern Greek should be classified in the Identical 
category.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 83A and language wals_code_som

text:
This datapoint is flat 
wrong. Gitksan, like all Tsimshianic languages, marks arguments with a 
set of what are called 'connectives' in the literature, following Boas. 
In the Interior Tsimshianic dialect continuum, which includes Gitksan 
and Nisgha, there are two basic types, referred to as 'determinate' and 
'non-determinate'. Determinate connectives, which are marked for number,
 introduce proper nouns, demonstratives, and (at least historically) 
independent pronouns; the single non-determinate connective marks common
 nouns. All the connectives are clitics, not affixes, and precede the 
first word of the argument phrase which they introduce. However, the 
non-determinate connective and some members of the determinate set are 
strongly enclitic, and therefore attach to the previous prosodic word, 
leading to a syntax-phonology mismatch of the kind found most famously 
in the Northern Wakashan language Kwak'wala. 
    So the Gitksan connectives are not affixes: and they are not 
definite either. On common nouns, the non-determinate connective occurs 
with every kind of argument, including those in strongly indefinite 
contexts (under the scope of negation and modals, in free choice 
environments, etc.). In fact, it is semantically vacuous.
    This mistake is particularly egregious in that the mutually 
intelligible Nisgha is marked as having *no* definite or indefinite 
article: but it has an identical connective system! And the closely 
related Coast Tsimshian system is given still a *third* value 'definite 
distinct from demonstrative'! It is true that demonstratives are 
distinct from the connectives in all Tsimshianic languages - but no-one 
has ever described the connectives as definite.

The particle "omen" 
makes it explicit that the speaker is reporting what a third person has 
said. This evidentiality marker is always inserted in between the 
lexical verb and the inflected auxiliary:

Maria     joan   omen da

"(It's said that) Mary has left"

post.title: Datapoint for feature 30A and language wals_code_eng

text:
Colloquial Welsh 
definitely has a preverbal negative, and reference to Watkins gives it. 
It is "d," explained in the reference as historically a reduced form of 
"nid." The example in the reference is "D oes dim dyn yma," or maybe "D 
oes ddim dyn yma;" I don't remember which and Google preview won't show 
me the page right now for some reason. The two don't mean the same 
thing; the first means "There is no man here," and the seconds means 
"There isn't a man here. But both require the intial "D" (which is 
usually spelled together with the following verb "oes" 'there is'. All 
verbs which begin with a vowel require a prefixed "d" when the sentence 
is negative. So, the preverbal negative doesn't appear with all verbs, 
unlike formal Welsh, but where the shape of the verb permits it, it's 
not optional. Leaving it out is unacceptable to native speakers. Again, 
the reference is correct here.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 94A and language wals_code_gjj

text:
I would like to know 
why is Portuguese assigned no-inflectional future and Spanish is 
assigned inflectional future exists. Is this an error?

post.title: The Future Tense

text:
If it is an error or 
not depends on your point of view. The source given is Dahl(1985, 
171-72), which is available at 
http://www.ling.su.se/polopoly_fs/1.20608.1309106635!/menu/standard/file/Tense%26aspectsystems.pdf.
In
 this work, the inflectional form called Future tense in Portuguese was 
deemed not to be used generally enough to be treated as a 
grammaticalized future tense (it is in competition both with the present
 and with the periphrastic 'go' construction).  
This judgment was based on questionnaire data from two native speakers. 
It was really a borderline case - the Portuguese form fell just below 
the postulated limit. The criteria applied may of course be seen as too 
rigid, and it would have been desirable for this procedure to have been 
clarified in the chapter text.

post.title: The Future Tense

text:

subordinator in question in Guajajara is a word mehe 'when', discussed

post.title: Datapoint for feature 138A and language wals_code_dhi

text:
I agree with Daniel; 
there is a consensus (i.e. children get taught at school) that 
Serbo-Croatian does have seven different cases. As a native speaker, I 
am able to recognize and use their distinct functions within a sentence,
 and if one was ommitted or substituted by the other I would be able to 
tell the mistake. One academic resource I can find to support this claim
 is the following: Alexander, R. (2006). Bosnian, Croatian, Serbian, a 
grammar: with sociolinguistic commentary. University of Wisconsin Press.
 pp. 21-22

Parts of it sufficient to support the claim that there are seven 
distinct cases are available in the Google books preview.

Additionally, here's a resource in Serbian that says the same thing: 
Stanojčić, Ž., & Popović, L. (1997). Gramatika srpskoga jezika: 
udžbenik za I, II, III i IV razred srednje škole. Zavod za udžbenike i 
nastavna sredstva, page 70

There are some dialects, especially in South Serbia, that may use less 
than 7 cases (notably, one dialect only uses two, nominative and 
accusative). However, this is not in accordance with the normative 
grammar of the language, and definitely not what the majority of native 
speakers would identify as grammatical.

I hope this comment helps correct this uncertainty.

text:
Hi, I'm a native French
 speaker from France, I'm not a linguistic pro so sorry by advance for 
imprecision and maybe misunderstanding about difference between 
affective/logical express. I'm ask the question if the category "Clicks 
may express logical meanings" imply also languages which contain both 
(affective + logical) ?

If yes, you can add French language in it.
If no, I report you the French language case were the para-linguistic 
usages of clicks are present and enter in both categories (deduction 
from what I read on chapter 142) : it may express affective or else 
express logical depending of the kind of click and the 
circumstances/environments.

Here the cases which i can certified their existences, senses and usages
 in France and known/used by French locutors :
I/ Bilabial clicks [ʘ] ([ʘwa] when exaggerated):
1) It's a represention of a kiss. (logical ?)
1a) Use to communicate love, affection to interlocutor.
example: Je t'aime ! ʘwa ! (I love you ! [click] !)
1b) Use to communicate gratitude to interlocutor.
example: - Merde ! J'ai oublié mon portable. (- Crap ! I forgot my 
cellphone.)
- Je te prête le mien. (- I lend you mine.)
- ʘ ! ([click] ! similar to "thanks / you're a sweatheart")
1c) Express kiss at the sense of "bye, see you, see ya" when interrupt a
 communication (can be duplicate)
example: Bon j'y vais maman je raccroche ʘʘ (I'm leaving now mummy I 
hang up [click-click] similar to "bye bye / kiss kiss")
1d) (Sarcastically) Use as provocation. Litteraly "me too I love you" 
but means "Je t'emmerde ; je t'encule" (I fuck you)
example:- C'est quoi ton problème ? Tu cherches la bagarre ? (What's 
your problem ? You looking for troubles ?)
- ʘ ! ([click] ! similar to "I fuck you / go die")

II/ Dental clicks [ǀ] :
1) Express exasperation or irritation when long and alone (clearly 
affective meanings). "Nttt..." = pfff...
2) Meaning negative answer when quicly duplicate (clearly logical 
meaning). "Nt-t." = no, not yet, disagree, oppose)
3) Strong disapproving warning when repeted at least thrice and clearly.
 "Nt-t-t-t-t-t !" = stop!, don't even try!, don't do that!
4) Express impatience when repeted lightly and continuously (clearly 
affective meanings). "Nt-t-t-t-t-t..." = distraction to pass the time

III/ Alveolar clicks [ǃ] :
1) A way to say "In your face" to deride someone after a bad things 
happen to him.
example:- Tu ne devrais pas toucher ce câble, il est sous tension. (You 
shouldn't touch this cable, it's on tension.)
- Laisse faire les pros, ok ?... Aïe ! (Let do the boss, ok ?... Ouch !)
- Et [ǃ] ! Je te l'avais dit. (Et [click] ! I told you.)

IV/ Lateral clicks [ǁ] :
1) Meaning positive answer. (yes, it's done, agree, support)

I have a microphone, and I'm able to reproduce and record all that kind 
of clicks if you're interested by illustrations. Just manifest you here 
and leave your mail or let me know how to contact you.

text:
Dear WALS redactors,
the Basque word for "tea" is "te", a loan from Spanish and, therefore, 
of the same origin. There are several phonetic variants when you add the
 definite article "-a" ("tea", "tia", "teia"...), depending on the 
dialect. The variant "txe" ("txea" with definite article) does not come 
from "cha" but still from Spanish "te" with dialectal initial 
palatalization:

http://www.euskaltzaindia.net/index.php?option=com_oeh&view=frontpage&Itemid=413&lang=eu

The
 example provided on WALS is "dute", which is an auxiliary form and has 
nothing to do with "tea", as far as I know.
Best regards,
Nerea

post.title: Datapoint for feature 116A and language wals_code_pol

text:
The order Noun-Genitive
 is certainly not the dominant order in present day Dutch. Although 
genitive case in general has almost disappeared from Dutch, it remains 
in a few constructions, the most productive of which is the possessive 
genitive like in 'Karels boeken' ('Charles's books'). Furthermore, some 
archaic use of partitive genitive can be observed, like in 'een der 
grootste fouten' (lit 'one the[GEN] biggest mistakes'). Here the 
genitive follows the numeral (in general not a noun). 

I would characterize present day Dutch with the dominant order 'Genitive
 - Noun,' with some relics from a mixed pattern, in which both orders 
were possible.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 38A and language wals_code_hun

text:
The Frisian example of 
an associative plural probably stems from an older descriptioin. The 
quoted form "hjar" is long extinct. Present-day Frisian has got an 
associative plural in the form "X en har" or "X en dy", the second form 
probably being the more common one. Although the etymology in 
recognizable in writing, the "en har" or "en dy" part are normally 
reduced in speaking, the /E/ turning into a schwa and the words loosing 
their word stress. The "en har" and "en dy" are probably enclitic forms 
or even suffixes in present-day Frisian.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 69A and language wals_code_wlf

text:
Korean has an obligatory future tense: ~(eu)lgeoya ([으]ㄹ거야).

For example: hada (하다/to do) vs. halgeoya (할거야/will do); anda (앉다/to sit) vs. anjeulgeoya (앉을거야/will sit), etc.

This also extends to adjectives: yeppeuda (예쁘다/to be beautiful) vs. yeppeulgeoya (예쁠거야/will be beautiful), etc.

One source: http://www.koreanwikiproject.com/wiki/index.php?title=%28%EC%9C%BC%29%E3%84%B9_%EA%B1%B0%EC%98%88%EC%9A%94

Also, a cursory Google search will reveal all of these examples as productive words.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 67A and language wals_code_kor

text:
Are you kidding? All 
conjugation / inflection in Finnish is synthetic! Verbs have the usual 
6+1 person forms, times 3 tempi; as well as 6 nominal forms, times 
cases... by my count, that's more than "2-3 categories"; of course we 
might be counting differently. Of course if you leave out nominal forms,
 you get only person, modus and tempus for each verb; but leaving out 
nominal forms is like saying "leaving out" isn't a verb because you can 
use it like a noun. Nominal forms bring in several categories: chosen 
infinitive (6 different), cases, person, and well, all those funny 
suffixes you can find in Finnish nouns.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 22A and language wals_code_fin

text:
Hello,

I am not a linguist--instead, I am a student of linguistics (on the 
undergraduate level) who speaks fluent German and French.
Though I understand this project focuses on a wider scope of languages 
than traditionally taught in universities; though I have little 
knowledge of languages outside English, French and the Germanic 
languages (as I have just discovered, a very narrow scope!); and though I
 have not read the literature given as a reference, I will say that I 
think saying that French is a language which builds its plural form 
primarily by a suffix is contrary to everything I've been learning in my
 French linguistics course.
Or, at the very least, is only applicable to the written language, which
 I don't believe is the form of the language examined here.
Indeed, in modern spoken French, the final letter of plural forms are 
not pronounced, as is well known--of course, this normally means that 
singular and plural forms are homophonous. (There is no spoken 
difference between "chat" and "chats".) Instead, to mark the plural, you
 use an article beforehand.
In fact, articles are the only functional way to mark number in French. 
The difference between "le (1) chat" and "les (>1) chats" can be 
realized as such in a phonetic transcription:[ləʃa] -- [leʃa]. As can be
 observed, it is the article beforehand that carries the difference 
between the two. Although in some cases, number is also post-determined 
("le cheval" -- "les chevaux") [ləʃɛval] -- [leʃɛvo], this only affects 
such a small class of nouns that renders it unproductive.
Of course, in written French, the difference is clear because there is 
an -s or some other similar ending on the end.
Other languages, like German, also use articles to differentiate number.
 What makes German different than French in this respect is a number of 
things: (1) the plural articles are sometimes allomorphic with other 
singular articles (ex. "die Katze" [the cat] and "die Katzen" [the 
cats]), (2) plural endings in German are realized in speech (ex. "die 
Katzen" is pronounced [di: katsn] and is clearly opposed to "die Katze" 
[di: katsə]), and (3) though there are cases in which the plural and 
singular are the same ("der Bäcker" {the baker} and "die Bäcker" {the 
bakers}), this never happens in the feminine and forms only a small 
class of masculine and neuter nouns whose number is only marked by the 
article beforehand. Traits like this mean that German's primary way to 
code plurality is indeed by use of a suffix, even when there are 
exceptions.
On the other hand, French codes plurality almost exclusively by using 
one of the plural clitics "des" or "les". In certain cases, this must be
 derived from context, so that even a case like "Il y a beaucoup de 
chevaux." (There are many horses.) where only the -aux ending shows 
plurality morphologically can hardly be taken as an exception seeing as 
the word "beaucoup" lexically already codifies plurality. (Compare with 
Eng. "a lot of", which also codifies plurality lexically so that plural 
endings are here technically superfluous and there is no question that 
the word "deer" in "a lot of deer" is plural.)

Indeed, I understand there's a lot of problems with any phenomenon in 
French. Still, I fail to see how French can be classified as having a 
plural suffix given the aforementioned information...
And I would be interested to see what other people have to say.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 33A and language wals_code_fre

text:
If "Est-ce que" can be 
used to mark a question, it is not the only way, especially in written 
French.

The word order can also be used, when this is done, your exemple "Est-ce
 que le président vient?" becomes "Le président vient-il?"

In fact the "est-ce que" form is seen as a less "éducated" way of 
speaking than the one using the word order to express a question.

In addition, in verbal conversation, as in Catalan, a polar question can
 also be expressed purely by the intonation: "Le président viens?"

Here are 3 ways of asking "Are you coming tonight?"

Venez-vous ce soir?
Est-ce que vous venez ce soir?
Vous venez ce soir?

post.title: Numeral Bases

text:
The sources for 
"Mangghuer" are not actually all dealing with the same variety. 
Therefore, the features listed are not actually all relevant to this 
variety. Todaeva worked primarily with Mongghul, the variety of "Tu" or 
"Monguor" spoken in Huzhu County and surrounding areas. In contrast, 
Slater's materials are from the Minhe area, and reflect the variety 
called Mangghuer. In sum, the features given here for "Mangghuer" are 
not all in fact relevant--some properly belong to Mongghul instead. For 
more specific information, researchers could start with Janhunen's 2003 
volume "The Mongolic Languages", which treats Mongghul and Mangghuer as 
separate languages and gives an introduction to their respective 
linguistic features.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 102A and language wals_code_anj

text:
No, there is no error, 
but because of the way examples from chapters were automatically added 
to the set of examples for online WALS, this example is indeed 
confusing.  Anna Siewierska cites this Anejom example in her chapter to 
illustrate an example of a subject marker that cannot be bound to the 
verb and which therefore by her criteria does not count as verbal 
subject marking. 

The language has suffixes for the P, but only when they are pronominal; 
there is no object suffix when there is an overt noun phrase denoting 
the object, as in the example cited.

Hence the language is correctly classified as “Person marking of only 
the P argument”.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 138A and language wals_code_chp

text:
I don't know which kind
 of prohibitive construction in Japanese is referred to, but my 
knowledge of Japanese suggests that none of the constructions use the 
normal imperative with a special negative. Take "Don't drink (alcohol)!"
 as an example:  

For the purpose of contrast, I would list some basic constructions for 
"Drink!":

(1) Nome.           Impolite form.
(2) Nonde kudasai.           Polite form.   
In addition, there exist some constructions in which another verb is 
used, which I am not going to discuss.

On constrast, "Don't drink" would be:
(1) Nomu na.           nomu is the indicative form (and can never be 
used as imperative), and na is a prohibitive particle, so this 
construction is "special imperative + special negative".
(2) Nomanaide kudasai.     Here the construction is verb-negative 
mark-imperative mark. I would treat this as "normal imperative + normal 
negative".

post.title: Datapoint for feature 71A and language wals_code_jpn

Northern Paiute does, 
in fact, have definite articles. These are historically related to 
demonstratives that have been reduced. The appear as proclitics on the 
noun phrase and, in the singular, are sensitive to a binary case 
distinction--nominative versus non-nominative.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 82A and language wals_code_crn

text:
On the WALS-maps, the 
Neo-Aramaic dialect of the Jews of Arbel is situated in Israel. But the 
language community was actually situated in Iraqi Kurdistan, not in 
Israel. It just so happened that the speakers of this language that 
Geoffrey Khan was able to work with had moved to Israel following the 
exodus of Jews from Iraq in the early 1950's. It would therefore be more
 realistic to move the point on the map to the original location of the 
speech community in Iraqi Kurdistan (see the Introduction to Geoffrey 
Khan's grammar) - and it would also make more sense of the striking 
structural commonalities between this variety of Neo-Aramaic and the 
Kurdish spoken in the region, which are evidently (in part) areally 
determined.

text:
@Omar: Spanish does 
have [β] [ð] and [ɣ] though... But I agree on that Spanish has a 
distinction between voiced and unvoiced plosives. The justification 
given for it having no voicing distinction is:

"Note that Spanish is not treated as having a voicing contrast in 
plosives since the sounds written with the letters b, d, g are not 
pronounced as plosives in most of their occurrences in speech but as 
voiced fricatives or approximants. Spanish therefore belongs to the 
final group of languages in this classification, those with a voicing 
contrast in fricatives but not in plosives."

"...most of their occurrences in speech..." - which implies that they 
are plosives in some environments and I'd say that voicing is 
distinctive there - word-initially.

text:
Lucas: French does not 
exhibit a vigesimal structure in the range 70-79. As you say, '70' is 
soixante-dix, i.e., 6 x 10 + 10, not *trois-vingt-dix 3 x 20 + 10 which 
would be expected for a vigesimal system. Compare this to 
quatre-vingt-dix '90', i.e., 4 x 20 + 10, which clearly is vigesimal.

post.title: Numeral Bases

text:
The basque word ‘“dute”
 for “tea” is attested in Lower Navarre, and it is a loan from French 
“du thé”. Thus “dute” is derived from Min-nan Chinese “te”.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 138A and language wals_code_bsq

text:
Surely the fact that 
the numbers from 61-79 in French are formed as a set of 20, explicitly 
stemming from the word for 60, makes them vigesimal: \soixante-quinze\, 
not *\soixante-dix-cinq\ which would be the form expected if 
soixante-dix followed the pattern for decimal multiples of 10, e.g. 
trente-cinq.

The fully decimal system can be heard in Belgium: septante, 
quatre-vingts (a decimal number here despite its meaning), nonante + un,
 deux, trois, quatre, cinq; never using onze, douze, treize, quatorze, 
quinze.

post.title: Numeral Bases

text:
I agree, and it surely 
complicates the analysis. However, I disagree that they should be seen 
as vigesimal; rather, I would view them as mixed, as '75' (in France) is
 neither the decimal *soixante-dix-cinq / *septante-cinq or the 
vigesimal *trois-vingt-quinze, but the mixed soixante-quinze.

text:
Regarding the 
statement, that there is no glottalized consonants in Tagalog:

there is a glottal stop in Tagalog with no letter assigned to it in the 
Tagalog alphabet. However, there are a number of omographs in Tagalog 
where the semantics depend solely on the presense or absence of the 
glottal stop at the end of the word. 
The glottal stop is usually put as /q/ in the linguistic papers.

Should the glottal stop be referred to the glottalized consonant, or 
not?

text:
The grammar by Haenisch
 is misleading. Gorelova (2002: 597), for instance, calls the markers 
n(i), o and nio "interrogative particles". I my opinion both 
descriptions are false, however. We are rather dealing with enclitics 
(or an enclitic group in the case of =ni=o), similar to the surrounding 
languages.

Evidence for this claim can be found, among other things, in the fact 
that the markers show a "low degree of selection with respect to their 
hosts" (Zwicky 1985: 299): =ni, for instance, can attach to nouns 
(turgun=ni), verbforms (gisure-mbi=ni), or participles (bi.he=ni). It is
 always the last element to attach to the host, nothing can attach to it
 except another enclitic (=ni=o).

Gorelova, Liliya M. 2002. Manchu grammar. Leiden, Boston, Köln: Brill.
Zwicky, Arnold M. 1985. Clitics and Particles. Language 61.2, 283-305.

Andreas Hölzl, Munich, Germany

text:
Gumuz has both head and
 dependent marking.  In Northern Gumuz, both subjects (which are marked 
differently whether A or S arguments) and objects can be marked on the 
verb.  Because it is a marked nominative langauge with a split system, 
dependents, namely S and A arguments, are marked with nominative case 
postverbally or for emphasis.

post.title: Datapoint Gumuz / Locus of Marking in the Clause

text:
In Possessive Noun 
Phrases, the possessor is marked with the prefix /alá-/ in Southern 
Gumuz and the prefix /lá-/ in Northern Gumuz.  In addition there are 
distinct constructions for inherently possessed nouns. Thus, Gumuz, 
follows a dependent marking pattern for possessive noun phrases.

post.title: Datapoint Gumuz / Locus of Marking in Possessive Noun Phrases

text:
As for the affixation 
index, Gumuz is boarderline between \moderately suffixing\ and showing 
equal amounts of prefixation and suffixation.  According to the formula 
given on this website, Gumuz is 60% suffixing and 40% prefixing.  This 
is true for both Northern and Southern Gumuz.

post.title: Datapoint Gumuz / Prefixing vs. Suffixing in Inflectional Morphology

text:
Gumuz has marked 
nominative case postverbally and for emphasis.  Nominative is marked 
with the /á-/ nominative prefix.  One could also argue that /alá-/ 
(Southern Gumuz) and /lá-/ (Northern Gumuz) are genitive case prefixes.
  However this latter prefix may be a prepositional proclitic.

post.title: Datapoint Gumuz / Position of Case Affixes

text:
There are five 
vigentiad from 1 to 100. The first, forth and fifth ones have the same 
vigesimal scheme (units from 1 to 19, soixante-et-un is a reliqua of old
 french, where -et- was before every unit); only txo vigentiad have a 
decimal scheme (units from 1 to 9). 
Up to the XVIII° century, we could find \six-vingt, spet-vingt, ... 
quinze-vingt, but deux-vingt, trois-vingt and cinq-vingt were not used.
In the XVII° century, mathematician used septante, octante and nonante 
with a pure decimal scheme from 21 to 99, but the grammarian Vaugelas 
convinced the Academy not to used this numeral system. Condorcet tried 
also to introduce a more rational system - with duante or duente instead
 of vingt, but his proposition was never adopted.
The French linguistic numeral system has a mixed vigesimal/decimal 
organisation up to 99, with a prevalence for the vigesimal scheme.
(sorry for my very bad English)

text:
The Faroese stress 
system is identical to how things work in the Central Scandinavian 
languages (Swedish, Danish, Norwegian), i.e no fixed stress. (Only 
Icelandic still has primary stress among the North Germanic languages.)

These matters are described correctly in Höskuldur Thráinsson 
(Þráinsson), Hjalmar P. Petersen, Jógvan í Lon Jacobsen, Zakaris Svabo 
Hansen: Faroese. An Overview and Reference Grammar. Tórshavn, 2004.

post.title: Datapoint Faroese / Fixed Stress Locations

text:
How does "a certain" 
mean indefinite? As far as I understand, "aru" is used in a plural 
semidefinite sense: "Aru hito wa sou omou" ある人はそう思う 'some people/certain
 people think so.' I don't know if this is an argument con or pro the 
classification here. But in Japanese there is certainly nothing like the
 a/an of English. The "aru" is more like the Russian "nekie/nekotorye": 
некие/некоторые люди так думают 'some people think so.' And Russian is 
classified as having no definite or indefinite article.

text:
Official and literary 
Italian has a person-oriented system with a three-way contrast: pron. 
"questo" adv. "qui" (near speaker); pron. "codesto" adv. "costì" (near 
hearer); pron. "quello" adv. "lì" (away from speaker and hearer).This 
system works also in Italian spoken in Toscana and Central Italy.

Each of the WALS

from one author to another.  The author for this chapter used a sample

post.title: Datapoint for feature 44A and language wals_code_fre

text:
Being a Vietnamese 
myself, I'm sorry to say this but there are very clear gender 
distinctions when it comes to Vietnamese 2nd and 3rd person pronouns. In
 conversations, Vietnameses really take into account people's social 
roles by using the proper pronouns for them, most of which have their 
own male and female versions. For example: we have "thầy" for male 
teacher and "cô" for female teacher, "anh họ" for male cousin and "chị 
họ" for female cousin, etc.
The only cases where there are no such distinctions is when the 
conversation occurs between peers, or people who have the same age.

post.title: Datapoint Vietnamese / Gender Distinctions in Independent Personal Pronouns

text:
Matthew S. Dryer - that
 is incorrect. There is no distinction of any kind in Farsi prounouns, 
either among sexes, or among human/non-human. Here are the translation

I/My - Man
You/Your - Toh
He/Him/His/She/Her/Her/It/Its - Oon
We/Us/Our - Ma
You/Your (plural) - Shoma
They/Them/Their - Oonha

There is never a distinction, so I must apologise when I say that the 
map is incorrect in marking Farsi as a gender neutral in only 3rd 
person.

sentence describes gender of the person or object! Pronouns are not

alone doesn't make much sense in Polish. And also each role has male and
 female word to tell the same. Example: nauczyciel - male teacher, 
nauczycielka - female teacher.

text:
According to UPSID (), 
Lithuanian does have /l/, and Bella Coola has lateral obstruents, so 
these must be technical errors. Georgian, Khmer and Yakut are given 
(along with Ket and Yukaghir) as having a velarised dental/alveolar 
lateral approximant, which should have been counted as a kind of /l/. 
The same probably goes for what Pashto has, namely a palatoalveolar 
lateral approximant.

Dear Henry Davis and 
Matthew Dryer,

I have read some of the great work you have done.
I have realised that not much is written on the Ligbi language, from the
 Niger-congo family group, and the Mande sub group. As a native speaker,
 I intend embarking on a research project on the the Ligbi language by 
next year. Since not much has been written about it, I would like to 
start with the phonological aspect of the language, as suggested by my 
lecturers/ Professors... Otherwise, I had wanted to conduct the research
 as an endangered language, for which I could get a grant from 
SOAS(School of Oriental and African Studies - London). I would 
appreciate very much your suggestions and contribution towards the 
success of this research project.
Many thanks and best wishes,
Elias Williams

post.title: Negative Morphemes

text:
Hello,
 I am a Greek native speaker and I think that you have misplaced the 
Greek language on the feature "Chapter Ordinal Numerals".
Cardinal -> Ordinal Numerals in Greek are:
Ένας -> Πρώτος
Δύο -> Δεύτερος
Τρεις -> Τρίτος
Τέσσερις -> Τέταρτος
Πέντε -> Πέμπτος
Έξι -> Έκτος
Έφτά -> Έβδομος
Όχτώ -> Όγδοος

so I was wondering which is the "First, second, three-th" rule here?
There is no direct rule (except if you consider the stem of the word 
which may also be a bit problematic. For example
Έφτά (Efta = 7) -> Έβδομος (Ebdomos = 7th) takes the stem 'εφτά' and 
transforms 'φ' into 'β' (same category of consonants) adds the ending 
'-ομος'
Όχτώ (Ohto = 8) -> Όγδοος (Ogdoos = 8th) transform 'χ' or 'κ' to 'γ' 
(same rule here) and adds an ending '-οος' not '-ομος' for example.

Anyway I am just reporting this. You make generalization so you are to 
decide.

With respect 

Georgios Orfanidis

post.title: Datapoint Maori / Zero Marking of A and P Arguments

text:
Hello, wondering how to
 interpret 33A and 34A when the two appear to be in conflict (e.g., 33A 
says no nominal plural but 34A says how nominal plural is applied). This
 situation occurs in seven languages: Alyawarra, Arrernte (Mparntwe), 
Coptic, Kana, Mapudungun, Ngalakan, Nias, Oromo (Harar), Pero, and 
Tauya. Appreciate clarification, thanks!

post.title: Coding of Nominal Plurality

text:
Thank you for bringing 
these to our attention.  Let me respond as the author of Chapter 33.

First, it is important to consider the following general point:

1.  The chapters have different authors and no attempt was made to make 
the different chapters consistent with each other.
2.  Different authors occasionally used slightly different criteria.
3.  There are often borderline cases.  While I attempted to always apply
 the same criteria, the fact that the data for my database has been 
collected over a period of over thirty years means that occasionally I 
was not consistent in applying exactly the same criteria in deciding 
borderline cases.

It is also important to “read the fine print”.  In Chapter 33, the 
feature value “No plural” is more accurately defined in “The final type 
shown on the map are languages apparently lacking a morphological plural
 ...”.  In other words, this feature value leaves open the possibility 
that a language of this type might code plurality by a separate word; it
 only claims that the language doesn’t code plurality on the noun 
itself.  The reason for defining this feature value in this way is that 
in the earlier years collecting data for my database, I did not look for
 coding of plurality by separate words.

This last factor explains the inconsistency in the coding of Coptic and 
one of two elements in Mparntwe Arrernte (Wilkins 1989: 129) that Martin
 Haspelmath (the author of Chapter 34) treated as coding plurality.  Now
 that I am aware of these, the coding of both of these languages for 
Chapter 33 will be changed from No Plural to Plural Word.

Another factor behind some of the inconsistencies is that I did not 
count something as a plural marker unless its meaning was simply 
plurality.  Some languages have markers of “collectivity”, which are 
close to being plural markers but have the added meaning that the set 
denoted forms a well-defined group.  One of the phenomena in Mparntwe 
Arrernte that Haspelmath apparently treated as a coding of plurality is a
 marker of collectivity (Wilkins 1989: 110).  The same is true of one of
 the phenomena that Haspelmath treated as a plural marker in Tauya.  On 
the other hand, I treated a word in Mapudungun as a plural word on the 
basis of Augusta (2003).  But it is clear from Smeets (2008), the source
 used by Haspelmath, that this word is a collective marker, not a plural
 marker, so the value for Mapudungun for Chapter 34 will be changed to 
No Plural.

The suffix in Ngalakan that Haspelmath apparently treated as a plural 
marker, I did not, since it has a more specific meaning.  It is a suffix
 that when added to symmetrical kin terms (like ‘brother’) has 
reciprocal meaning, e.g., denoting a set of people who are brothers of 
each other.  When added to asymmetric kin terms, like ‘father’, it 
denotes the set consisting of the father and the set of individuals that
 he is father of.

The description of the number-like suffixes in Alyawarra by Yallop 
(1977: 85) suggests that none of them are really simply plural markers. 
 However, I missed a statement at the foot of p. 88 that says that one 
of them can be used as just a plural marker.  So Chap. 33 should code 
Alyawarra as having a plural suffix.

I did not treat a language as having plural marking if it occurs only on
 a very small number of nouns.  But my coding of Harar Oromo as lacking a
 plural suggests that many years ago I had a somewhat more lax standard 
as what counts as “very small”.  Today, I would consider three or less 
to be very small.  But Harar Oromo has plural marking for at least ten 
nouns, so by my current criteria, it should be coded as having a plural 
suffix.

On the other hand, one of the phenomena that Haspelmath seems to have 
treated as a plural marker in Tauya, I did not so treat since it is 
described as “rarely attested”.

Another marginal case is presented by Pero, where a small number of 
nouns have plural forms, all of which are suppletive.  I did not treat 
languages where all plurals of nouns were suppletive as having a plural 
since in such cases I consider plurality to be part of their lexical 
meaning rather than grammatical plural (somewhat analogous to a noun 
meaning ‘wife’ being lexically feminine, but not reflecting a feminine 
gender), though one could just as easily analyse them differently.

In the case of Nias, my coding it as having a plural prefix is clearly 
an error.  There is an associative plural prefix, but I do not in 
general treat associative plural affixes as plural affixes, so Nias 
should be coded in Chapter 33 as lacking a plural.

The last inconsistency is Kana.  Although Ikoro (1996) describes a word 
that he calls a specifier as having collective meaning, the discussion 
suggests that it is simply a plural marker since in the absence of a 
possessive pronoun, the noun phrase is interpreted as indefinite (while I
 consider a true collective marker as inherently definite).  I’m not 
sure why Haspelmath did not include it (since it is somewhat analogous 
to the plural forms of articles in Mparntwe Arrernte and Coptic).

post.title: Coding of Nominal Plurality

post.title: Datapoint Ju|’hoan / Other Roles of Applied Objects

text:
French is 
additive-quantitatively case asymmetrical, it has case-marking on some 
pronouns, for instance in “il le lui donne” (he/it gives it to him/her”,
  the third person singular pronoun appears in the nominative masculine 
(il), accusative masculine (le) and dative (lui).
Or compare “le chat qui voit la souris” (the cat that sees the mouse), 
using “qui” = relative pronoun subject, and “le chat que voit la souris”
 (the cat that the mouse sees), using “que” = relative pronoun object. 
For the latter, the word order “le chat que la souris voit” is also 
possible but verb-subject inversion in such relative clauses is common.

text:
The claim that German 
has two dominant orders (SVO, SOV) is completely wrong as everyone who 
knows more about German than Lederer's translation of Schulz & 
Griesbach knows. This has been established already in 1886 by Oskar 
Erdmann, and in the typological literature since 1981 by Mallinson &
 Blake:

Erdmann: „Durchaus unrichtig ist es, wenn manche Grammatiker hier dem 
Subjektnominativ besondern Anspruch auf die erste Stelle einräumen 
wollen“ (It is completely incorrect if in these cases some grammarians 
want to grant special priority to the nominative subject for the first 
position of the clause). Erdmann (1886:183; §206). “

Mallinson & Blake: "The order used for a stylistically unmarked 
version of John saw Mary in German would be SVO, too, but to simply call
 German an SVO language would disguise the verb-second nature of its 
word order." Mallinson & Blake (1981:129).

Frans Plank (2009:61; review of WALS) “There is not a bit of flexibility
 about where the German verb is.”

... and the authors know it but prefer - for ununderstandable reasons - 
posting a misleading information.

post.title: Datapoint French / Negative Morphemes

text:
I would call the root 
of the Finnish reflexive pronoun \itse-\ at least an \almost 
obligatorily possessed noun\. The oblique cases of the pronoun usually 
require the possession pronominal, f. ex.:\itse-ni : itse-si: itse-nsä\ 
(myself, yourself, him/herself); \itse-lle-ni: itse-lle-si: itse-lle-en\
 (for myself, for yourself, for him/herself) etc. The oblique cases are 
occasionally used without the possession pronominal in a passive 
sentence or in other occasions when the meaning of the expression is 
very general, like \lahjaksi tai itselle\ (as a present or for 
one-self). I would call \itse-\ an obligatorily possessed noun, perhaps 
not entirely, but as a basic rule.
The root word \itse\ is entirely an other matter. It is called the 
\nominative\ in most grammatical descriptions, and it does appear as a 
free word form. Functionally, however, this fascinating word form is not
 a nominative at all: It hardly ever appears as a subject of the 
sentence (which is the main \job\ for any other noun in nominative in 
Finnsih) and it's meaning is rather \by one-self\ than plainly \self\. 
It is mainly used as an adverbial modifier, f.ex \leivo-n itse\ means \I
 bake bread or cookies by myself, without help, with my own hands or 
instead of buying them\. I would not consider \itse\ as a free word form
 a noun at all (any more). It has rather become an adverb.

text:
I don't have access to 
your source, but I could not find any source stating that negative 
words, especially negative verbs, normally appear in postverbal position
 - much less that preverbal position is not possible.

It is not true that negative words in Udmurt do not appear preverbal, 
instead, preverbal position is the most frequent position and I have 
rarely, if ever, come across postverbal negative elements. For example 
Suihkonen (1995, 315): "The order of the negative verb can vary. Its 
neutral position is in front of the main verb, but it can also be 
located before the object NP or valency adverbial phrase."

Apart from negative verbs, negative particles are also preverbal: 
Winkler (2011, 109): "Negationsverb und Negationspartikel [...] stehen 
unmittelbar vor them Verb." ('Negative verb and negative particle stand 
immediately in front of the verb.', translation by me).


References
-------------

@book{suihkonen_1995,
	author = "Suihkonen, Pirkko",
	publisher = "Helsinki: Suomalais-Ugrilainen Seura",
	title = "{Udmurt – English – Finnish dictionary with a basic grammar of
 Udmurt}",
	year = "1995"
}


@book{winkler_2011,
	author = "Winkler, Eberhard",
	publisher = "Wiesbaden: Harrassowitz",
	title = "{Udmurtische Grammatik}",
	year = "2011"
}

text:
Because of the 
complexity of the maps showing position of negative morphemes and 
because of the need for short feature value names, it was not always 
possible to employ names for feature values that are self-explanatory.  
As explained in http://wals.info/chapter/144#144H, "No NegSVO" does not 
mean that the language does not allow NegSVO.  What it means is that if 
the usual negative construction involves a single negative word, this 
won't be NegSVO and that if the language allows double negation, the 
dominant order will not be one in which the position of one of the 
negative morphemes will be initial.  According to my data, Finnish 
satisfies the first of these since the negative construction involves a 
single negative word and the dominant position is not initial (but 
SNegVO).

 the chapter on definite articles will distinguish negative morphemes 
which are separate phonological words from those that are separate words
 by morphosyntactic criteria but phonologically bound.  The definite 
article in Amharic is an example of the latter.  The current chapter 
collapses these, basing the classification on morphosyntactic criteria 
rather than phonological criteria, but I agree that this is confusing.

nouns are not dependent-marked. Only pronouns are. The map is supposed 
to show marking of nouns rather than pronouns when they differ, so 
English should appear on the map as "P has no marking."

text:
The modern korean 
language has different words for blue(파랑,청青,남藍) and green(녹綠). However 
if you disregard the sino-lexicon(청,남,녹), pure/native korean is a 
'grue(파랑)' language. Nowadays the native 'grue(파랑)' and its many derived
 forms (파란,퍼런,푸른) are mostly used for blue and a chinese loan word '녹綠' 
is used for green. Nevertheless some forms of the native 'grue' 
(especially 푸른) are still in common use today to discribe both blue-ness
 and green-ness. While the sino-lexicon 청青 is mostly used to discribe 
blue-ness, there are rare occasions it is used to discribe green-ness, 
and is used like a grue word. 청과青果 meaning 'green vegetables and fruits'
 and 청테이프 'green tape' a type of green coloured duct tape very common in
 korea.

post.title: Datapoint Korean / Green and Blue

text:
The Spanish pronoun and
 article system has three genders as much as English but leaves the 
neuter (which lacks a plural) to genderless things such as events or 
unspecific things and to make abstract nouns from adjectives more or 
less. El ella ello el la lo ese esa eso este esta esto aquel quella 
aquello. Spanish should be counted as having three genders. el bueno the
 good (male, masc thing) la buena the good (female, fem thing), lo bueno
 what is good, the good (quality, etc). Ello though has died out in 
colloquial speech being replaced by lo eso esto aquello. More examples: 
el dicho the saying la dicha the aforesaid (female, fem thing) lo dicho 
what was/is said. el/ese/este/aquel niño esa/esa/esta/aquella niña 
eso/lo que nos pasó (that thing that happened to us/what happened to 
us). That or that thing can be translated eso or aquello without the 
word for thing because the gender or the thing is unspecified; whereas 
ese aquél would mean that male or masculine gender thing and be 
translated that one.

text:
Sharma (1989: 224–255) 
wrongly describes NAdj as the dominant order. However, Bunan displays 
dominant AdjN order. To be sure, NAdj order does exist in the language, 
but it is restricted to contexts in which the head noun is indefinite. 
AdjN order is not subject to any restrictions. Comparative evidence 
suggests that Bunan originally only possessed AdjN order and that the 
NAdj pattern has arisen through longstanding contact with neigboring 
Tibetan speaking communities.
Reference: Widmer, Manuel (2014). A descriptive grammar of Bunan. Bern: 
University of Bern dissertation.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 81B and language wals_code_hun

text:
I am tired of this 
classification of the european languages as 'accusative'. In fact most 
are far from being accusative owing to their heavy use of 
reflexive/anticausative verbs or (in Greek and Albanian) mediopassive, 
in Slavic, Romance, and even in Germanic although less so. In Spanish 
this is widespread as in se me olvidó and lo olvidé, both meaning I 
forgot. This goes all the way back to indo-european, hence in english 
hear vs listen, see vs look. Even though English lacks this impersonal 
use of the reflexive, many of the Slavic and Romance do and in Spanish 
its usage is extensive. Lo dejé vs. se me quedó both meaning I left it 
with different degrees of volitionality. In other words, european 
languages have regular ways to make unaccusative verbs from unergative 
ones unlike English which can only use the "passive". Se me quemó vs. lo
 quemé, both meaning I burned it, but with different degrees of 
volitionality. So stop equating them to english with this inaccurate 
label accusative.

text:
I don't see why English
 is marked as " 'We' the same as 'I' ". The verb "be" shows a 
distinction in inflection between "We" and "I" for both the past and the
 present: "We are" vs. "I am" and "We were" vs. "I was." Furthermore, 
English doesn't even have an inclusive/exclusive distinction, so it 
seems like it should be put in the category "No inclusive/exclusive."

post.title: Datapoint English / Inclusive/Exclusive Distinction in Verbal Inflection

text:
The verb "to be" is 
arguably a last leftover of an earlier structure in which English had 
different "I" and "we" forms. However, currently this is not 
productively part of English anymore. 

Further, the categories are defined so that only one can apply, so the 
current category implies "no inclusive/exclusive" as explained in the 
text.

text:
I don't agree with the 
value "Unrelated."
 I read Hinds (1986:109) and thought that the content was generally 
correct although there are another words that may make the conclusion 
doubtful. For example, 彼の (かの, kano). It often precedes 有名な (ゆうめいな, 
yūmei-na) or 高名な (こうめいな, kōmei-na), both of which mean "renowned".

かの有名な田中角栄も
kano yūmei-na Tanaka Kakuei mo
that renowned Kakuei Tanaka also

かの is probably related to 彼 (かれ, kare, "he"), a kind of masculine 
third-person singular pronoun.

 Furthermore, the deictic forms have their anaphoric pronoun 
counterparts in respect:
この (kono, "this"), その (sono, "the"), あの (ano, "that") vs. こいつ (koitsu, 
"this guy"), そいつ (soitsu, "the guy"), あいつ (aitsu, "that guy")

 Taking everything into consideration, it may be more precise to give a 
value "Partially related to demonstratives" to Japanese. Or are they 
only ignorable things?

text:
Hi there,

actually there is a numeral classifier for animates or especially humans
 in Sinhala which is postponed to the adjectival form of numerals or 
even suffixed to the roots of numerals like 'one' and 'two'.

It is:

(-)dena or (-)denâ (definite forms)
(-)den-ek (indefinite form)

Etymologically it is said to be based on a former noun meaning 'people, 
person'. Nowadays one can find an entry for dena/denâ meaning 'cow' or 
denotating 'the female of any animal'etc. 
See for example page 28 in: Matzel, Klaus and Premalatha 
Jayawardena-Moser 2001: "Singhalesisch - Eine Einführung". Wiesbaden: 
Harrassowitz.


You should check Marathi as well again. There should be numeral 
classifiers in that language as well.

Cheers
N. Kiel

I'd like to comment not
 only on this datapoint, but in fact on the relevant chapter, as the 
Latvian examples are cited and discussed there. In fact, the 
interpretation in the chapter is correct, as Latvian does indeed exploit
 the PRS.2SG form as the 2SG imperative. The situation with the 2PL 
plural is a bit tricky. The example here in WALS is not exactly the 
dedicated form, which would be rather Runājiet! (where -iet- is a 
suffix/ending specific for the imperative only)

The tricky thing is that the PRS.2PL in the imperative function indeed 
occurred in old texts and still occurs in non-standard Latvian, but the 
form here in the chapter is even not the present, but the past form of 
the verb 'to say, to speak' (the present would be Runājat!)

text: As far as I am aware, Romanian has five cases, not two.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 49A and language wals_code_rom

text:
No, by the criteria 
assumed for this chapter, Romanian has only two cases morphologically. 
What are called nominative and accusative is a single case 
morphologically and what are called genitive and dative is a single 
case. And what is called the vocative is not a case by the criteria of 
the chapter since the vocative does not signal a semantic or grammatical
 relationship between two elements. The tradition of describing Romanian
 as having five cases simply reflects imposing on the language 
categories that come from Latin and that are not motivated by Romanian 
facts. Missionaries describing languages without case would sometimes 
describe the language as having six cases, simply imposing Latin 
categories on the language.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 49A and language wals_code_rom

text:
North Saami does not 
use the normal negative and the normal imperative in the prohibitive. 
Rather, a special negative form appears. The ordinary imperative for 
2.sg of the verb boahtit 'come' is boađe. The negated present indicative
 is it boađe 'you do not come'. Here it encodes negation and 2 sg (the 
negation is an auxiliary and agrees with the subject). The negated 
imperative 2sg is ale boađe 'do not come!'. Ale encodes neg imp 2sg, and
 it only appears in negated imperatives.

text:
"only one language, 
Dumu (Sko; Sandaun, Papua New Guinea), is currently known to have no 
velar consonants"
-Tahitian has no velar consonants (Conversational Tahitian by D.T. 
Tryon, pg. 1).
-Xavante has no velar consonants (The Amazonian Languages, Cambridge 
University Press 1999, pg. 178).  
-I've heard that Piraha can also be analyzed as having no velar 
consonants, almost as well as it can be analyzed as having no nasals. 
It's also interesting to note that all the languages that have no velars
 (that I've heard of) have very phonemic glottals (both stop and 
"fricative"- though I can't speak for Dumu). 
-I've heard that Kiribati, though it has no phonemic fricatives, has s 
as an allophone of t before i.
-If we're counting languages that have voiced stops as allophones of 
nasals as having no nasals (like Maxakali and Piraha), then we might as 
well throw I'saka into the mix (according to Wikipedia).

Perhaps I don't 
understand how the criterion of multiple politeness distinctions is 
decided upon. Looking at Davies (1981), but also Davies (1991 = [Davies,
 John. 1991. Marked pronouns and verbs for marked social relationships 
in a Chadic and a Papuan language. Man and a Half: Essays in Pacific 
Anthropology and Ethnobiology in Honour of Ralph Bulmer. (Pp. 397-405). 
Edited by Andrew Pawley. Auckland: Polynesian Society.], it is clear 
that the DUAL and the PLURAL are both employed to signal affinal respect
 relationships (in both 2nd and 3rd person pronominals). The DUAL is 
employed for affines of the same social gender from speaker and the 
PLURAL is employed for affines of different social gender.

text:
Apart from being a 
native speaker, I am currently working on the Questions Formations of 
the Yoruba Language. The information provided in Rowland (1969:118) that
 polar questions are formed by intonation only in the language, on which
 this map heavily relies for the typology of the language is completely 
false. Yoruba does not use intonation at all in relation to all 
interrogative forms, be it polar or wh. The language uses particles 
only, and the manner of occurrence is slightly different from what 
obtains in other languages. If you need a copy of my study, please 
contact me through the given e-mail address.

text:
The reference given in 
this feature for Basque, despite its title, is unrelated to the concept 
of antipassive reviewed here. There may be an antipassive construction 
in Basque (it is a matter of discussion, as they seem rather biclausal 
constructions, not really antipassives; in addition, the former 
absolutive object does not change into oblique, but remains the same; 
cf. (In press) Zuñiga F.; Fernández, B. Grammatical relations in Basque.
 In Balthasar Bickel & Alena Witzlack-Makarevich (ed.) Handbook of 
Grammatical Relations; their example 40a):
(1) Jonek   liburu asko irakurri du.
    Jon.ERG book.ABS many read
(2) [Jon    [liburu  asko irakurri-a] da.]
     Jon.ABS book.ABS many read.PFV-DET is
    ‘Jon has read many books.’
But the article mentioned here does not even make any reference to this 
type, but rather to a verb that could pattern with the existing 
alternation in a very small group of verbs between an erg-abs and 
abs-inst pattern, similar to that of Spanish (recordar algo vs. 
acordarse de algo; cf. Rijk, Rudolf de. 2003. Antipasiboak euskaran. 
[Antipassives in Basque.] In: J.M. Makatzaga & B.Oyharçabal (eds.), 
Euskal gramatikari eta literaturari buruzko ikerketak XXI. mendearen 
atarian. Gramatika gaiak. Iker 14-1, 255-278. Bilbo: Euskaltzaindia).

post.title: Datapoint Basque / Antipassive Constructions

text:
The typology on map92A 
may need to be extended to accommodate Yoruba. The language uses four 
particles for polar questions. Two among these are distributed clause 
initially, one comes as the second item within a clause while the last 
comes at right periphery of the clause. There is no such language that 
has its particles distributed at all of these positions in the sample 
provided here. So, I suggest you add another value to the map.

post.title: Datapoint Yoruba / Position of Polar Question Particles

text:
The plural clitic only 
attaches to object (and oblique) noun phrases in transitive sentences 
without a copula (Elders 2000: 393). In this case, it could be analyzed 
as a postpositional clitic.

post.title: Datapoint Mundang / Position of Case Affixes

text:
Sorry, I forgot to cite
 a crucial bit in (2000: 392): "L’enclitique du pluriel -râ a son propre
 comportement syntaxique. Il peut se combiner avec un grand nombre de 
catégories: nom, déterminants nominaux, préposition, pronom sujet, 
déterminatif restrictif, copule, verbe. Il est postposé à la fin d’un 
syntagme; la seule exception en est le syntagme nominal sujet d ’une 
proposition verbale et dans ce cas-là, il est postposé au verbe."

So the plural enclitic on NPs appears to distinguish NPs in subject 
function (unmarked) - with the exception of subjects in sentences with a
 copula - from NPs in non-subject function (marked).

post.title: Datapoint Mundang / Position of Case Affixes

text:
I don´t understand why 
the WALS has included Canary Island Spanish as a different language than
 standard Spanish. Besides, the only feature reported for this variety 
is 142A, and it has exactly the same value than the one that appears for
 (standard) Spanish. I suggest omitting this datapoint for future 
editions of WALS.

post.title: Datapoint Spanish (Canary Islands) / Para-Linguistic Usages of Clicks

text:
Of course Canary Island
 Spanish is not a \different language\ than Standard Spanish; several 
WALS maps include more than one dialect of the same language, and for 
good reason — in many cases, WALS features cross-cut individual 
languages, with different dialects of the same language displaying 
different feature values.  As you correctly point out, this is not one 
of those cases; for this feature, the Canary Islands dialect has the 
same feature value as the standard language — but negative data can be 
just as important as positive data.  In the case at hand, 
para-linguistic clicks exhibit interesting areal patterns in Africa and 
the Mediterranean region, so it was of interest to see what happens in a
 geographically remote variety of Spanish.  In fact, in an update to 
this map (in preparation), there will be substantially more data from 
various dialects of Italian and Arabic.

post.title: Datapoint Spanish (Canary Islands) / Para-Linguistic Usages of Clicks

text:
I understand professor 
Gil's comments, and I defintely agree with him in general, and 
especially about languages such as Italian or Arabic, in which "dialect 
distinctions" are really very important. But that does not seem to be 
the case of Spanish (or English). As I see it, the only WALS feature in 
which it is worth making a distinction between Standard Peninsular 
Spanish and other varieties is feature 19A (presence of uncommon 
consonants). This is because Peninsular Spanish speakers usually use the
 phoneme /th/, while most other varieties (almost all Latin American 
speakers, and also most Canary Island speakers) merge that phoneme with 
/s/. However, WALS does not report that difference, and in feature 19A 
it classifies Spanish as a language in which the uncommon consonant "th"
 is present (although it is not present in the varieties of Spanish 
sponken by 90% of the Spanish speakers). In the case of feature 142A, 
conversely, all Spanish speakers use clicks to express "affective" 
rather than "logical" meanings, and that is why I think that it is not 
worth it to distinguish between Standard Spanish and Canary Island 
Spanish.

post.title: Datapoint Spanish (Canary Islands) / Para-Linguistic Usages of Clicks

text:
It is misleading to 
state that Swahili has a double object construction. I don't recall that
 this was even claimed by Ashton 1947. Although both patient and 
recipient are formally unmarked, in a ditransitive construction the 
object agreement on the verb can only refer to the recipient, never to 
the patient, which would warrant the assignment of the value 'secondary 
object' to this feature. I have written a lengthy paper on this in 1996 
(in German), which can be accessed here: 
https://www.academia.edu/1831007/Die_Grammatischen_Rollen_des_Objekts_im_Swahili.

text:
Finnish actually 
doesn't combine case and number. talo 'house' talo-ssa (Inessive) in 
the/a house, talo-i-ssa in (the) houses. -i- is a marker of PL in 
oblique cases while -t marks Plural in the Nominative and Accusative. 
SG:ACC=SG.GEN, PL.ACC= PL:NOM
          SG          PL
NOM talo      talo-t
GEN  talo-n  talo-j-en
ALL   talo-lle talo-i-lle
ABL   talo-lta talo-i-lta
ADE  talo-lla  talo-i-lla
ELA   talo-sta  talo-i-sta
ILL   talo-on    talo-i-hin etc.

post.title: Case Syncretism

text:
I think Serbian and 
Croatian should not be classified as "Question particle". There are at 
least three strategies for polar questions (all examples are "Are you 
going tomorrow?"):

Ideš li sutra? - standard in Croatian and Serbian. The verb has to go to
 the 1st position + particle "li".

Da li ideš sutra? - standard in Serbian, disputed in Croatian (but 
widely used) - the two-word particle "da li" is put to the position #1.

Ideš sutra? - colloquial; only intonation is changed. The verb is most 
often at the position #1, but it's not mandatory, you can ask "Sutra 
ideš?" if you want to stress "sutra" 'tomorrow'

There are more colloquial variants, mostly with various 1st position 
particles (Je li, Jel, Dal), alternatively spelled as one or two words.

Source: I'm a native speaker.

text:
I took a look at the 
Bantu languages in this sample - among them, Swahili has a one-past 
system (like Arabic), while the others (Zulu, Sesotho, Kikuyu, Luganda, 
Mwera, Luvale) all discern 2-3 remoteness categories. What is the 
"normal case" for a Bantu language? Are these examples of category II 
representative?

On the borders of Bantu territory, the map shows Khoekhoe in the same 
category.
In East Africa, Nandi (Kalenjin, Nilotic) also distinguishes three types
 of past tense - today's past, yesterday's past, and remote past, each 
with a kV- prefix (thus ka-lenjin - I told you). Nandi is not contained 
in the sample.

Other than these two, there seem to be no non-Bantu languages in 
immediate Bantu vicinity with remoteness distinction. 
If Bantu is more or less uniform in this regard, this could inspire the 
suspicion that Khoekhoe and Nandi adapted to Bantu.
Or is there evidence for the opposite direction?

post.title: Case Syncretism

text:
Chapter 21 restricts 
attention to case on nouns while Chapter 28 includes case on either 
nouns or pronouns. Since English has case on pronouns but not on nouns, 
there is no inconsistency. I suspect the different coding for Japanese 
reflects two competing analyses of case markers in Japanese, whether 
they are considered morphology or not. Since these chapters are by 
different authors, there is no reason for there to be consistency across
 these chapters.

post.title: Case Syncretism

text:
Hello, I am a native 
French speaker and, in my view, French should be classified as using a 
plural clitic as its primary means of encoding plural. Indeed, even 
though most French are written with a -s ending in the plural, it is 
actually silent. Adjectives with such an ending sometimes occur (please 
forgive my spelling of this word if incorrect) and then, provided that 
the following adjective or noun begins by a vowel sound, it is is 
effectively pronounced. Nonetheless, in spoken French, only determiners 
always code plural.

In /mes chers amis/ 'my dear friends', the -s ending of /chers/ is 
pronounced, but in /mes chers parents/, neither the -s of /chers/ nor 
that of /parents/ is pronounced.

Accordingly, in /les cinq continents/ 'the five continents ' the -s 
ending of /continents/ is silent, therefore only the determiner /les/ 
'DEF.ART.PL' codes plural (in fact a more a precise analysis would be 
/l-/ 'DEF.ART' /-es/ 'PL').


I hope I've expressed myself clearly enough. Also, I hope the person 
responsible for this chapter will answer me as soon as possible as to 
wether my point of view is justified or not.
