 how_many-SG.M 3.DAT-SG.M COP.SUBJ.PRES-PRES-SUBJ.SG Peter-SG.M
- - - -
Resuming, the Italian language has two ways of the 'particle' kind 
(using the genitive preposition "di", equivalent to English 'of' or, 
only with pronouns, "che", equivalent to English 'than', cognate with 
the French 'que'), a way of the 'locational' kind (using noun "rispetto"
 + allative/adessive preposition "a", equivalent to English 'to', to the
 Maasai 'to', and to the Siuslaw '-tc'), and a way of the 'conjoined' 
kind (first clause in the indicative + comparative + "di" or "che" or 
"rispetto a" + second clause in the subjunctive).

2/4 of 'particle' feature
1/4 of 'locational' feature
1/4 of 'conjoined' feature

result: 'mixed' feature (if I understand correctly)

post.title: Comparative Constructions

text:
Italian language, when 
using the word equivalent to the English 'want' referring to a desire 
related to the future, uses infinitives (as in Turkish in example (1)a. 
and in Zulu in example (1)b.)
(indicative/conditional of 'volere'/‘voler' + ({reference to a future 
time or 'andare a'}) + infinitive) for an imperfective desire of a 
future imperfective event
(the indicative ‘voglio'/‘vuoi'/‘vuole'/‘vogliamo'/‘volete'/‘vogliono' 
is used to express a strong desire (or a list of strong desires), while 
the conditional 
‘vorrei'/‘vorresti'/‘vorrebbe'/‘vorremmo'/‘vorreste'/‘vorrebbero' is 
used to express a weak desire (or a list of weak desires) or as a 
politer way to express a strong desire (or a list of strong desires) )
- "(io) voglio/vorrei andare, salutare i nostri parenti e tornare (a 
casa/al lavoro)." = "I want to go, greet our relatives, and go back 
((to) home/to (the) work (place))."

(indicative/conditional of 'volere'/‘voler' + 'che' + {reference to a 
future time} + present subjunctive of 'stare'/‘star' + adjective) for 
imperfective desire of a future perfective state
for example:
- "(io) vorrei che {domani} io stia meglio" = "I want that {tomorrow} I 
will be finer."
- "(io) vorrei che {domani} tu stia bene/meglio" = "I want that 
{tomorrow} thou/you will be fine/finer."
- "(io) vorrei che {domani} stia bene/meglio" = "I want that {tomorrow} 
he/she/it will be fine/finer."
(indicative/conditional of 'venire'/‘venir' + past participle) for an 
imperfective desire of a future perfective event
for example:
- a.
- - "(io) vorrei che {(per) domani} il nuovo stadio venga 
finito/completato." = "I want that {(by) tomorrow} the new stadium will 
be finished/completed."
- - "(io) vorrei che {(per) domani} lo stadio nuovo venga 
finito/completato." = "I want that {(by) tomorrow} the newer stadium 
will be finished/completed."
- b. "(io) vorrei che {entro due giorni ((a partire) da oggi)} lo stadio
 venga finito/completato." = "I want that {(with)in two days ((starting)
 from today)} the stadium will be finished/completed.

(conditional of 'avere'/‘aver' + masculine singular past participle of 
'volere'/‘voler' + infinitive) for perfective desire of a present 
imperfective event
(conditional of 'avere'/‘aver' + masculine singular past participle of 
'volere'/‘voler' + infinitive of auxiliary 'avere'/‘aver' or 
'essere'/‘esser' + past participle) for perfective desire of a past 
perfective event
(conditional of 'avere'/‘aver' + masculine singular past participle of 
'volere'/‘voler' + ('che') + past subjunctive) for perfective desire of a
 past imperfective event
(conditional of 'avere'/‘aver' + masculine singular past participle of 
'volere'/‘voler' + ('che)' + past subjunctive of auxiliary 
'avere'/‘aver' or 'essere'/‘esser' + past participle) for perfective 
desire of a past perfective event

(1)
- b. (infinitive)
- - "(Io) voglio/vorrei giocare con lui."
- - (io) vogli-Ø-o/vol-Ø-r-ei gioc-a-r-e con l-u-i
- - (1.SG.NOM) want.PRES.SG.1-PRES-SG.1/want-{irregular thematic 
vowel}-INF-COND.SG.1 play-{thematic vowel}-INF-INF COM/INSTR 
3.PREP\ACC-M-SG
- - "‘I want to play with him.'"
Italian language has the 'subject is left implicit' in case of a 
reference to a desire related to a future event respect to the time the 
speech is said or written.

post.title: ‘Want’ Complement Subjects

text:
First of all, the 
analysis of the example 5 could be more inaccurate, here a more accurate
 analysis
(5)
- a.
- - "(lui/egli/esso/lei/ella/essa) Glielo scrive affinché 
(lui/egli/esso/lei/ella/essa) se ne accorga." ("affinché" is compound of
 "a" + "il" + "fine" + "che")
- - (l-u-i/ell-gli/ess-o/l-e-i/ell-a/ess-a) Glie=l-o scriv-Ø-e 
a=i-l=fin-Ø=che (l-u-i/ell-gli/ess-o/l-e-i/ell-a/ess-a) se ne accorg-Ø-a
- - (3-M-SG/3-SG.M/3-SG.M/3-F-SG/3-SG.F/3-SG.F) 3.DAT=3.ACC-SG.M 
write-IND.PRES-SG.3 ALL\ADE=SG.M-DET=purpose-SG.M=that 
(3-M-SG/3-SG.M/3-SG.M/3-F-SG/3-SG.F/3-SG.F) 3.DAT.REFL + 3.REL.ACC + 
notice-IND.PRES-SUBJ.SG
- - "‘He/She/It writes it for him/her/it in order that him/her/it 
notices it.’"
This is not the only way to say/write this sentence, there is also a 
commoner way.
- b.
- - "(lui/egli/esso/lei/ella/essa) Glielo scrive per farglielo notare."
- - (l-u-i/ell-gli/ess-o/l-e-i/ell-a/ess-a) Glie=l-o scriv-Ø-e per 
fa[c]-[e]-r-Ø=glie=l-o not-a-r-e
- - (3-M-SG/3-SG.M/3-SG.M/3-F-SG/3-SG.F/3-SG.F) 3.DAT=3.ACC-SG.M 
write-IND.PRES-SG.3 PURP CAUS-{thematic vowel}-INF-INF=3.DAT=3.ACC-SG.M 
notice-{thematic vowel}-INF-INF
- - "‘He/She/It writes it for him/her/it to cause him/her/it noting 
it.'"
(the agentive/donor argument 'he/she/it' of the first clause is who 
writes the information (including computers, robots, ...), the theme 
argument 'it' is the information, and the addressee/recipient argument 
'him/her/it' is who gets the information (including computers, robots, 
...) )

The third-person singular present indicative has a zero marking (the 
same feature is shared with the other present indicative forms) of both 
mood and tense,
while the third-person singular present subjunctive has a zero marking 
of the tense (shared with the other present subjunctive), and no 
informations about the person ('io me ne accorga', 'tu te ne accorga', 
'lui/egli/esso se ne accorga', 'lei/ella/essa se ne accorga', 'noi ce ne
 accorgiamo', 'voi ve ne accorgiate', 'essi se ne accorgano', 'esse se 
ne accorgano', 'loro se ne accorgano')
The example (5)a. is without dubts a case of 'deranking' as for the 
definition used for this chapter.
The example (5)b., instead, is on the border between 'deranked' and 
'balanced'
(1)
- "(io) Venni al centro degli affari a/per comp(e)rare (dei) libri."
- (io) ven-n-i a=i-l centr-o di=g-l-i affar-i a/per comp(e)r-a-r-e 
(di-Ø-i) libr-i
- (1.SG.NOM) come-IND.FAR_PST-SG.1 ALL=SG.M-DET centre-SG.M 
GEN=SG.M-DET-SG.M affair-PL.M ALL/PURP buy-{thematic vowel}-INF-INF 
(PART-DEF-PL.M) book-PL.M
- "‘I went downtown to buy (some) books.'"
(2)
- a.
- - "(io) stampai un-a copia di questo capitolo al fine di fartelo 
guardare."
- - (io) stamp-a-i un-a copi-a di que-st-o capitol-o a=i-l fin-e di 
fa(c)-(e)-r-Ø=te=l-o guard-a-r-e.
- - (1.SG.NOM) print-IND.FAR_PST-SG.1 INDEF-SG.F copy-SG.F GEN 
that\this-this-SG.M chapter-SG.M ALL\ADE=SG.M-DET purpose-SG.M GEN 
CAUS-{thematic vowel}-INF-INF=2.SG.DAT=3.ACC-SG.M look-{thematic 
vowel}-INF-INF
- - "‘I printed out a copy of this chapter in order for you to look at 
it.'"
- b.
- - "(io) stampai un-a copia di questo capitolo per guardarlo."
- - (io) stamp-a-i un-a copi-a di que-st-o capitol-o per guarda-r-Ø=l-o.
- - (1.SG.NOM) print-IND.FAR_PST-SG.1 INDEF-SG.F copy-SG.F GEN 
that\this-this-SG.M chapter-SG.M PURP look-INF-INF=3.ACC-SG.M
- - "‘I printed out a copy of this chapter to look at it.'"
(4)
- a.
- - "L'uomo viene a mangiare del pollo."
- - l-'=uom-o ven-Ø-e a mangi-a-r-e di-i-l poll-o
- - DEF-SG.M=man-SG.M come-IND.PRES-3.SG ALL eat-{thematic 
vowel}-INF-INF PART-SG.M-DEF chicken-SG.M
- - "‘The man came to eat chicken.’"
- b.
- - "L'uomo viene a mangiar del pollo."
- - l-'=uom-o ven-Ø-e a mangi-a-r-Ø di=i-l poll-o
- - DEF-SG.M=man-SG.M come-IND.PRES-3.SG ALL eat-{thematic 
vowel}-INF-INF GEN=SG.M-DEF chicken-SG.M
- - "‘The man came to eat some(thing) of the chicken.’"
In examples (4)a. and (4)b., the usage of the infinitive is of the 
'balanced' type, while the preposition "a" may be either allative (base 
meaning, as in "venire/andare a lavorare"), adessive (as in 
"rimanere/stare a lavorare") depending by the verb preceding.
So, Italian language may have both a 'deranked' feature as in (5)a. and a
 'balanced' feature as in (4)a. and (4)b. this means that the Italian 
language, for the purpose of map 125A, has a 'balanced/deranked' 
feature.

post.title: Purpose Clauses

text:
In examples (1)a., 
(4)a, and (4)b., the preposition "a" is part of the verb "venire" 
("venire a" = "to come (in)to"/"venire qui/qua//lì/là a" = "to come 
(into) here//there at/to"), not a purposive preposition.
(x)
- a.
- - "venire a casa/qui a casa"
- - "to come to home/here at home"
- b.
- - "venire all'ospedale."
- - "to come to the hospital."
- c.
- - "venire a Londra."
- - "to come (in)to London.
(y)
- “venire al lavoro”/“venire (qui) a lavorare”
- "to come (here) to work"
These examples (x)a., (x)b., (x)c., and (y), remove any left dubt 
regarding the assignment of examples (4)a. and (4)b. to the 'balanced' 
feature.

post.title: Purpose Clauses

text:
In Italian language, 
for the secondd-person singular, the contrast between present indicative
 and subjunctive exists for second- and third-conjugation verbs, but not
 for first-conjugation verbs
{regular first-conjugation without special orthophonetic rules}
"(1.SG) amo"  "che (1.SG) ami"
"(2.SG) ami"  "che (2.SG) ami"  "ama!"
"(3.SG) ama"  "che (3.SG) ami"  "ami!"
"(1.PL) amiamo"  "che (1.PL) amiamo"  "amiamo!"
"(2.PL) amate"  "che (2.PL) amiate"  "amate!"  "amiate!"
"(3.PL) amano"  "che (3.PL) amino"  "amino!"
{regular second-conjugation without special orthophonetic rules}
"(1.SG) credo"  "che (1.SG) creda"
"(2.SG) credi"  "che (2.SG) creda"  "credi!"
"(3.SG) crede"  "che (3.SG) creda"  "creda!"
"(1.PL) crediamo"  "che (1.PL) crediamo"  "crediamo!"
"(2.PL) credete"  "che (2.PL) crediate"  "credete!"  "crediate!"
"(3.PL) credono"  "che (3.PL) credano" "credano!"   "che (3.PL) credino"
  "credino!"
{regular third-conjugation without special orthophonetic rules}
"(1.SG) dormo"  "che (1.SG) dorma"
"(2.SG) dormi"  "che (2.SG) dorma"  "dormi!"
"(3.SG) dorme"  "che (3.SG) dorma"  "dorma!"
"(1.PL) dormiamo"  "che (1.PL) dormiamo"  "dormiamo!"
"(2.PL) dormite"  "che (2.PL) dormiate"  "dormite!"  "dormiate!"
"(3.PL) dormono"  "che (3.PL) dormano"  "dormano!"  "che (3.PL) dormino"
  "dormino!"
{regular third-conjugation with "Ø/ìsc" 'gradation' and 
third-conjugation 'ìsc'-related orthophonetic rules}
"(1.SG) finisco"  "che (1.SG) finisca"
"(2.SG) finisci"  "che (2.SG) finisca"  "finisci!"  "finischi!"
"(3.SG) finisce"  "che (3.SG) finisca"  "finisca!"
"(1.PL) finiamo"  "che (1.PL) finiamo"  "finiamo!"
"(2.PL) finite"  "che (2.PL) finiate"  "finite!"  "finiate!"
"(3.PL) finiscono"  "che (3.PL) finiscano"  "finiscano!"  "che (3.PL) 
finischino"  "finischino!"

post.title: Purpose Clauses

text:
These are examples of

text:
Dear website 
administrators,

I was surprised to find that, according to your database, Romanian would
 not have a (compound) perfect. The same goes for Map 68.1: ‘Have’ 
perfects in Europe. 

This must be a misunderstanding. In fact, in Romanian, the compound 
perfect, based on the Lat. HABERE + past participle, has overwhelmingly 
replaced the simple perfect in spoken language (except for the region of
 Oltenia) and has also experienced the aoristic drift (the same way as 
French and Northern Italian). Moreover, like in modern Spanish, the 
auxiliary based on HABERE (avea) is the only option, while an auxiliary 
corresponding to 'to be' is not in use.

It is easy to find evidence for the existence of a perfect in Romanian 
in the literature; for example, the following example is from the 
Romanian Grammar by Sarlin (2013, 244).

Am citit o carte 'I read a book'

Luni am mers la teatru 'On Monday I went to the theatre'

Furthermore, in Corocaju's Romanian Grammar  
(http://www.seelrc.org:8080/grammar/pdf/stand_alone_romanian.pdf) we 
find:

Eu am cântat un cântec românesc. I sang a Romanian song.; (p. 119)
Am lucrat mult săptămâna asta. I have been working a lot this week. (p. 
134)


Best regards,
Ilpo Kempas

post.title: Politeness Distinctions in Pronouns

text:
Чукча - не читатель, 
чукча - писатель.
Fellas, can you read? Matthew Dryer explained four years ago that in a 
typologically non-biased sense gender means a temporally stable division
 of the lexicon in formally recognizable classes according to whichever 
criterion. Here, the criterion is animacy. It is very interesting what 
all of you are saying about the modern spoken Persian, but note for 
Christ’s sake that the indicated value concerns the literary Persian. Or
 is it simply the case that you don’t quite master it?
There are reliable sources that confirm the animacy distinction between 
u/vey on the one hand and aan on the other hand (e. g. Rubinčik, J. A. 
2001. Grammatika sovremennogo persidskogo literaturnogo jazyka. Moskva: 
Izdatel’skaja firma “Vostočnaja literatura” RAN, p. 170). Irrespective 
of the fact that aan is actually a demonstrative, one cannot forgo using
 it when referring pronominally to inanimate referents in 3SG. 
Therefore, it is warranted to say that gender distinction exists in this
 combination of grammemes in this grammatical domain of literary 
Persian. 
Can you first do some research and express your doubts then? I wasted a 
quarter of an hour of my precious lifetime reading the invalid ones 
expressed in this section and doing the ensuing research for you.

post.title: Datapoint for feature 44A and language wals_code_prs

text:
A correction:
gender is a temporally stable division of the entire nominal lexicon 
according to whichever criterion in classes that are formally 
recognizable outside the part of speech ‘noun’.

text:
Locus of Marking in the
 Clause in Hungarian should be described as "Double marking", not 
"dependent marking". Hungarian verbs have an entire separate "definite 
object conjugation", with different verb suffixes used when the verb has
 a definite object, distinct from the verb suffixes used when the verb 
has no object or an indefinite object. This is a clear example of 
morphosyntactic marking of the syntactic relations of the clause 
(subject and object) on the head of the clause (the verb). In 
combination with the accusative case suffix on the noun that is the 
object, this is a clear example of double marking in the clause.

post.title: Datapoint Hungarian / Locus of Marking in the Clause

text:
On the Locus Marking in
 Possessive Noun Phrases map, I believe Hausa should be listed as HEAD 
MARKING (RED), not DEPENDENT MARKING (BLUE).
Using the same source listed on the map (Newman 2000), section 3.1.3. 
(Possessives) gives as an example rigar Sule [riga-r Sule] 'Sule's 
gown,' where the linker -r (feminine form) attaches to the head noun 
'riga' (gown). Also, in section 3.2.3. (Genitival nouns), dealing with 
abstract genitival noun phrasess, examples include ruwan zafi [ruwa-n 
zafi] 'hot water' (i.e. heat's water or water of heat) and maganin tari 
[magani-n tari] 'cough medicine' (i.e. 'cough's medicine' or 'medicine 
of cough'), where again, the linker particle -n (masculine form) 
attaches to the head noun.

post.title: Datapoint Hausa / Locus of Marking in Possessive Noun Phrases

text:
Dear Editors, 

I have just finished my PhD dissertation on epistemic modality in 
Amharic. In your study, the information on epistemic expressions in 
Amharic has been taken from Leslau, and quite right. The problem is that
 there are two expressions which could refer to the notion of epistemic 
possibility in Amharic: a modal auxiliary 'yǝhonall' (which you provide 
reference to) and another, less grammaticalized expression, 'yǝčǝlall' 
which I find a better equivalent of the English 'may'. 'Yǝčǝlall' is 
also polyfunctional and has gone through the same path of 
grammaticalization (from ability to epistemcity) as some modal verbs in 
SAE languages. I do not know how much you stick to the idea that an 
epistemic expression in a given language should be as closest an 
equivalent of the English 'may' as possible. The modal 'yǝčǝlall' comes 
from the verb 'čalä' (be able, can) but it gains the epistemic meaning 
only in the imperfective form preceeded by a complementizer 'lǝ-' + 
imperfective form of the main verb. Leslau was unaware of the existemce 
of this construction (at least he does not mention it explicitely in his
 reference grammar).  
Another important point is that there is a semantic difference between 
the two expressions and they are not mutually substituitable. What is 
then the range of meanings that fall under the lable 'epistemic 
possibility' in your study? Anything that can be successful translated 
into English as epistemic 'may'? But what meaning it conveys? What does 
it mean 'epistemic possibility' in your case?

With best regards,
Magdalena Krzyzanowska

post.title: Datapoint Amharic / Epistemic Possibility

text:
I kinda feel like 
French should be classified in "fixed stress" (last syllable), but it 
varies by dialect because of how the final schwa in nouns/adjives/verbs 
behaves (/ə/) - in Canadian dialects, the final schwa is very much just 
an less common optional epenthetic filler vowel added (often at the end 
of the sentence) to slow down speech (and in songs with a less popular 
version of the language) and is usually not used. In dialects from 
Southern France it's very much alive (so the value of 'no fixed stress' 
makes sense). Dialects from Northern France are somewhere in-between in 
behavior.

WALS features are

datapoint, you'd have to convince the author (in this case Anna 
Siewierska) to change it. Additional sources could help with that - but 
many WALS authors no longer really maintain their features, so the 
chance for changes in these cases is slim.

text:
This value appears to 
be wrong.

Tenishev (1997) does not mention a velar nasal in the consonant 
inventory.  However, this source is based mostly on Tenishev (1966), 
which inferred a consonant inventory (also lacking a velar nasal) from a
 53-word word list.  None of the words of Turkic origin appear to be 
ones where an /ŋ/ would be expected in cognates in other Turkic 
languages.

A much more comprehensive description of Fu-yü Gırgıs was presented by 
Zhen-hua and Imart (1987).  They include /ŋ/ in the phoneme inventory, 
and there are examples of its use throughout the description: (in their 
transcription system) čapčaŋ 'quickly', arašaŋ 'spa', anïŋ ‘his/her’, 
miniŋ ‘my’, -nIŋ ‘GEN’, ɢozuŋʁa ‘rabbit-DAT’, bariziŋ ‘you will go’, 
bardïŋar ‘you (pl) went’, and so on.

text:
Mapudungun is 
definitely a language lacking the inclusive/exclusive distinction, not a
 language with no distinction between 'I' and 'we'. 
While number is optional for third person, Mapudungun second person 
pronouns clearly distinguish singular, dual and plural.
Here is the relevant passage from the text used as a source (Smeets 
2008:97):
"Mapuche distinguishes three persons and three numbers. In the system of
 personal pronouns and that of personal suffixes, indication of number 
is obligatory for first and second person and optional for the third 
person. There is no inclusive/exclusive distinction. There is no 
male/female distinction.
The personal pronouns are:
iñche = I – 1s
iñchiu = We – 1d
iñchiñ = We – 1d"

post.title: Datapoint Mapudungun / Inclusive/Exclusive Distinction in Independent Pronouns

because the sources I consulted (and referenced) clearly state the

error on my side. I checked back and it was already in my original data 
files from 2002... I will add an issue to the WALS data, and it might 
then be changed at some point in the future. 

best
Michael (author of the chapter)

Hello! I notice that 
Welsh is marked as using a question particle to mark polar questions, 
but to the best of my knowledge that is not the case in modern standard 
Welsh, for example "He is going." would be "Mae o'n mynd.", while "Is he
 going?" would be "Ydy o'n mynd?", note the only difference being the 
first word, the verb 'is', and as far as I am aware, this is the case in
 most other situations as well, for example "Bwyton nhw", "They ate", vs
 "Fwyton nhw?", "Did they eat?".

distinction in demonstratives, not a two-way distinction. This is 
discussed in the cited Gruzdeva 1998, but must have been entered 
incorrectly. A more recent paper by Gruzdeva on Nivkh demonstratives can
 be found at the URL below.

http://www.linguistics.fi/julkaisut/SKY2006_1/1.3.2.GRUZDEVA.pdf

Dutch uses "zich" as 
its reflexive pronoun and "zelf" as its intensifier. The combination 
"zichzelf" is used in practically all cases of reflexivity where a the 
verb itself isn't reflexive.
"Hij schaamt zich." He is ashamed of himself.
"Hij ziet zichzelf." He sees himself.
"Hij ziet zelf." He sees (without any aid.)
"Hij zelf ziet." or "Hijzelf ziet." He himself sees.

These are truly distinct from each other. Thus, shouldn't this category 
be marked "distinct"?

text:
Portuguese most 
definitely has an inflectional future tense. If we take the verb «fazer»
 (to do), we'll have, in the indicative mode: farei, farás, fará, 
faremos, fareis, farão. Although, when speaking, most speakers will use 
the verb «ir» (to go) in the present with the infinitive of the verb in 
question like in «vou fazer» to express future, that construction can't 
be used when saying «I'll go» as «vou ir» is generally considered, both 
in Portugal and in Brazil, incorrect. The correct form would be «irei». 
We use this construction more formally, but its use is still widespread.

text:
This datapoint should 
be the second type, “Adjective may occur without noun, and without 
marking”. Cf. Newmark, Hubbard & Prifti (1982) Standard Albanian - A
 Reference Grammar for Students:
“In Albanian, adjectives become substantivized through the process of 
conversion; that is, they take on the attributes of nouns (including 
inflections) without the addition of derivational affixes or a shift in 
stress.” (p. 190)
Note that this applies to both “lexicalized substantivization” and 
“contextual substantivization”. (p. 191)
The confusing factor is that Albanian adjectives belong 
morphosyntactically to one of two classes, articulated (the majority) 
and unarticulated. Articulated adjectives are always preceded by an 
adjectival article (a proclitic) that inflects according to case, 
number, and gender, but the adjectival article is an integral part of an
 articulated adjective and is present whether the adjective determines a
 noun or stands by itself. (cf. op. cit. pp. 179–180)
I assume that the present value of this datapoint, “Adjective may occur 
without noun, obligatorily marked by preceding word”, is due to a 
misunderstanding of the role of the adjectival article. Unlike English 
‘one’, its role is not to mark the fact that the noun is missing.

post.title: Datapoint Albanian / Adjectives without Nouns

text:
I'm curious about the 
inclusion of Gela (Southeast Solomonic) in the group of languages with a
 definite word distinct from demontrative. Crowley (1985:159) cites 
Codrington, who demonstrates that Gela /na/ has "no reference to focus 
or definiteness". Crowley (2002:527-28) reverses this observation, 
claiming that Gela /na/ is a definite article, though half of his 
examples demonstrate 'incorporation' (i.e., no 'article' before the 
post-verb noun). More convincing are Rijkhoff's (2002:95, 185 n. 21) 
observations re. noun phrase markers in Oceanic languages--that they do 
not mark (in)definiteness. This is certainly the case in Doku (aka 
Lengo), Gela's counterpart in the Gela-Guadalcanal branch of Southeast 
Solomonic.

it really means "all common *classes* of consonants are present. 
Specifically, even though Arabic does not have a p sound, it DOES have a

terminology is explained in the introduction to the chapter this 
datapoint is associated with, "Chapter 1: absence of common consonants",
 in the introduction section of that chapter.

the English pronunciation of "shoot" and "seed", but the "u" in "Lu" is 
used to indicate a short unstressed schwa sound, not a long stressed

text:
Gatschet 1890: 467, 
471-474 states and shows very clearly that Klamath actually has a 
secondary-object construction, whereby the recipient or addressee of the
 ditransitive verb takes the same case suffix -ash as the direct object 
of a simple transitive verb, and the formal direct object of the 
ditransitive verb does not take this case suffix. It is true that 
animacy-marking is also involved here, as only persons and quadrupeds 
are marked with this case suffix -ash at all, whether as the direct 
object or as recipient / addressee. Naturally, in the vast majority of 
ditransitive verb constructions, the recipient / addressee is animate 
and the object given or thing told is not animate.
For the record, although it is not included in WALS yet, the related 
Plateau Penutian language Ichishkíin (Sahaptin) has the same 
secondary-object construction (Jansen 2010: 324), again based on the 
human object taking the case suffix, in this case -nan. But in 
Ichishkíin, unlike in Klamath, an inanimate direct object of a simple 
transitive verb *does* take this case suffix -nan (Jansen 2010: 160), 
although there are particular grammatical constructions where a human or
 topical object is marked with -nan but other objects are not.
It is notable that dependent-marking languages with inflectional noun 
case affixes and such a secondary-object construction are 
extraordinarily rare: WALS only identifies a few languages in Australia 
and in Papua New Guinea as having this combination of features.

text:
I noticed that Spanish 
language is counted among languages with double-marking, however, 
Spanish languages case-marking on noun is made only by use of 
prepositions (the same as in French language), and has only a 
person/numer concordance (person/numer/gender concordance in deponent 
intransitive perfective tenses and all passive tenses) with the subject 
and, as far as I know, no concordance at all with objects (except for 
so-called clitic forms of pronouns).
The same applies for French and Romanian languages.
In Italian language there is a similar situation, but with an optional 
concordance of the past participle with the direct object in so called 
"compound tenses" (the perfective counterparts of so called "simple 
tenses") of active conjugation.
So Spanish, French, Italian, and Romanian languages, if considering the 
one-word imperfective forms, have to be mapped as "P has no marking", 
while, if considering the two-word perfective forms, the Italian 
language (possibly also the Spanish, French, and Romanian languages, but
 I have no enough knowledge to state for these three languages), due to 
an optional head marking, have to be mapped as "Other types".

post.title: Locus of Marking in the Clause

text:
P.S.: clitic forms of 
pronouns are used only in place of nouns, not in addition of them, so 
they have not to be counted for map 23A, but may be considered for a 
future map 23B.
P.P.S.: while in Spanish language the use of so-called clitic forms (in 
practice they are verbal morphemes for concordance with arguments other 
than subject and agent-like argument, not pronoun forms, since nothing 
may stay between these morphemes and the verbal words to which they are 
applied (by affixation or apposition depending by language and verbal 
word)) of dative pronoun forms (indirect object) are obligatory also 
when the true pronoun is used, the use of clitic forms of accusative 
pronoun forms (direct object) excludes the use of the true pronoun, in 
Italian language the exclusivity of clitic forms against true pronouns 
applies also to dative case (indirect object).

post.title: Locus of Marking in the Clause

text:
For chapter 24, map 24A
 (I cannot comment on chapter 24 comments, so I comment here), in 
Spanish, Portuguese, French, and Italian languages, possessor has no 
case markings and genitive case is expressed by use of prepositions 
(between the possessor noun and the possessed noun; as in example 9 at 
chapter 24 in section about languages with no possessor marking), or by 
use of a possessive adjective in place of the possessor noun (with 
concordance by person and number with the possessor, and by gender and 
number with the possessed thing), not morphemes on nouns (as examples in
 section about language with dependent marking of possessors), only 
Romanian language distinguishes dative/genitive case against 
nominative\absolutive/ergative/accusative case by use of markings on 
(definite forms of) nouns (in the feminine singular this applies also 
with indefinite forms).
So Portuguese, Spanish, French, and Italian languages should be mapped 
as "Possessor has no marking", while Romanian language should be mapped 
as "Possessor is dependent-marked".

post.title: Locus of Marking in the Clause

languages I know.
Since in chapter 25 is specified that chapters 23 and 24 use the default
 option in case of multiple possible options, and examples for 
appositions are shown in section about zero marking, the result is:
for features 23A, 24A, and 25A, both Portuguese, Spanish, French, 
Italian, and English have to be mapped as "zero-mariking" (it would be 
"dependent-marking" if examples for appositions were in sections about 
dependent-marking), while Romanian language have to be mapped as

text:
For English language is
 the same for features 23A, and 25B, while features 24A, and 25A depend 
by if the genitive suffix "-'s" ("-'" in words ending by "s") is counted
 as default or not (since it is used with given nouns, but avoided with 
most common nouns).
If we consider English genitive suffix as default, English languages 
have to be mapped as having "head-marking" for feature 24A, and as 
"inconsistent or other" for feature 25A, otherwise, if we consider 
English genitive suffix as secondary, English have to be mapped as 
specified in the previous comment.

text:
In Romance language 
exists a suffix/interfix which is intensified by duplication ("-issim-" 
in Italian language), the suffix/interfix works as follows (I use 
Italian language in the examples, but this applies also to Portuguese, 
Spanish, Catalan, Occitan, French, Italian, Romanian, and other Romance 
languages):
bello (beautiful) -> bellissimo (very beautiful/much beautiful) ->
 bellissimissimo (very much-beautiful) -> bellissimissimissimo (very 
very-much beautiful) -> …
felice (happy) -> felicissimo (very happy/much happy) -> 
felicissimissimo (very much-happy) -> felicissimissimissimo (very 
very-much happy) -> …
felicemente (happily) -> felicissimamente (much happily) -> 
felicissimissimamente (very much-happily) -> 
felicissimissimissimamente (very very-much happily) -> …
forte (strong/forte) -> fortissimo (very strong/much 
strong/fortissimo) -> fortissimissimo (very 
much-strong/fortissimissimo) -> fortissimissimissimo (very very-much 
strong/fortissimissimissimo) -> …
fortemente (strongly) -> fortissimamente (much strongly) -> 
fortissimissimamente (very much-strongly) -> 
fortissimissimissimamente (very very-much strongly) -> …
piano (piano) -> pianissimo (pianissimo) -> pianissimissimo 
(pianissimo) -> pianissimissimissimo (pianissimissimissimo) -> …
fortemente (weakly) -> fortissimamente (much weakly) -> 
fortissimissimamente (very much-weakly) -> fortissimissimissimamente 
(very very-much weakly) -> …
pratico (practical) -> praticissimo (very practical/much practical) 
-> praticissimissimo (very much-practical) -> 
praticissimissimissimo (very very-much practical) -> …
praticamente (practically) -> praticissimamente (much practically) 
-> praticissimissimamente (very much-practically) -> 
praticissimissimissimamente (very very-much practically) -> …
…
(in music speech, the series forte -> … -> fortissimissimissimo 
-> …, and piano -> … -> pianissimissimissimo -> …, are also 
interlanguage-ised and internationalised).
May these be considered as full reduplication (of inflectional 
morphemes), or duplication of morphemes other than stems are not counted
 for feature 27A?

post.title: Reduplication

text:
1) answering to Beirne 
an to anywho else has similar questions/thoughts: gender is a property 
of the concordance between words, not a property of nouns, pronouns, 
adjective forms, article forms, etc., so state that English has three 
genders is correct since in English third person singular personal 
pronouns has gender concordance with nouns (do not confuse the overlap 
between gender and sex with the lack of gender distinction, and do not 
forget that in English "vessel" and "ship" have a feminine gender 
despite being asexual).
2) replying to yoandri: Spanish definite articles in the singular 
(el/la/lo), third-person singular personal forms (él/ella/ello), and 
demonstrative adjectives in the singular (este/esta/esto, ese/esa/eso, 
and aquel/aquella/aquello) have three forms (one masculine, one 
feminine, and one neuter), but two forms have the same concordance (the 
neuter forms have masculine concordance), so Spanish language has two 
genders.
3) the Italian and Romanian languages, despite having neuter nouns, have
 no neuter gender concordance, so they have only two genders (masculine 
and feminine, same as French, Spanish, and Portuguese)
Neuter nouns as "uovo" -> "l'uovo" ("egg", plural "uova" -> "le 
uova", archaic "ovo" -> "l'ovo", archaic plural "ova" -> "le 
ova"), "budello" -> "il budello" ("gut", plural "budella" -> "le 
budella"), and "paio" -> "il paio" ("pair", plural "paia" -> "le 
paia") in Italian and "autobuz" -> "autobuzul" ("bus"/"autobus", 
plural "autobuze" -> "autobuzele", "bilion" -> "bilionul" (UK 
"bilion"/US "trilion", plural "bilioane" -> "bilioanele") in Romanian
 have masculine gender concordance in the singular and feminine gender 
concordance in the plural (not neuter gender concordance as in Latin 
neuter nouns).
Italian language has also nouns which are neuter only in certain senses 
as "dito" -> "il dito" ("toe"/"finger", plural "dita" -> "le dita"
 without attributes or "diti […]" -> "i diti […]" with attributes), 
"braccio" -> "il braccio" ("arm", plural "braccia" -> "le braccia"
 if pertaining to a living being or "bracci" -> "i bracci" if 
pertaining to a robot, to a crane, or to another non-living being), 
etc., or historically mandatory and currently optionally as "carcere" 
-> "il carcere" ("prison", synonym of "prigione", plural "carceri" 
-> "le carceri"/"i carceri").
Italian language has also two particular exceptions, they are the words 
"orecchio"/"orecchio"/"orecchia" -> 
"l'orecchio"/"l'orecchio"/"l'orecchia" ("ear", plural 
"orecchi(i)"/"orecchia"/"orecchie" -> "gli orecchi(i)"/"le 
orecchia"/"le orecchie"), and "eco" -> "l'eco" ("echo", plural "echi"
 -> "gli echi"),
the first is the only Italian word having both one masculine inflection 
("orecchio"/"orecchi(i)"), one feminine ("orecchia"/"orecchie"), and one
 neuter ("orecchio"/"orecchia", now mostly deprecated due to syncretism 
of feminine-gender-concordance neuter-inflection plural form "orecchia" 
with feminine-gender-concordance feminine-inflection singular 
"orecchia"),
the second is the only Italian word whith an anti-neuter inflection (an 
anti-neuter inflection has a feminine-gender concordance in the singular
 and a masculine-gender concordance in the plural, while a neuter 
inflection has masculine-gender concordance in the singular and 
feminine-gender concordance in the plural),
since the word "eco" begins by vowel and, so, the definite article 
alliterates to "l'" (a syncretic form with no gender distinction in the 
singular and, during thirteenth century, also with no number distinction
 in the feminine, in modern grammar the alliteration of definite article
 in the plural is deprecated), in modern Italian it is accepted an 
alternate masculine-gender concordance in the singular, to see the 
feminine concordance, we have to apply an attribute with gender 
distinction in the singular, for example, if we use the qualificative 
adjective "bello" ("beautiful"), we have "la bella eco"/"il bell'eco" in
 the singular and "i bei echi" in the plural.

post.title: Number of Genders

text:
Language cannot have 
less than 1 gender, less than 1 grammatical number, or less than 1 
grammatical case, so languages mapped as with "none" genders must be 
mapped as with "one" gender, instead.

post.title: Number of Genders

text:
P.S.:
If a language has less than 2 genders (as Basque, Vietnamese, and 
Chinese), the only gender is the "common" gender.
If a language has less than 2 grammatical numbers (as Vietnamese, and 
Chinese), the only grammatical number is "plural".
If a language has less than 2 grammatical cases (as Vietnamese), the 
only grammatical case is "nominative" (also known as "absolutive").

post.title: Number of Genders

text:
1) For the same reason,
for feature 30A, value "none" have to be replaced by value "one" (both 
in chapter and on map),
and in those for features 31A, and 32A, value "no gender" have to be 
replaced by value "one gender" (only on map).
2) In chapters 30, 31, and 32, word "gender" have to be replaced by its 
hypernym "class", since all "gender systems" are "sex-based class 
systems".
3) Since animacy-based class systems as those of many Niger-Congo 
languages are considered with multiple classes (mistakenly called 
genders in the chapters), also the animacy based system found in Basque 
language have to be considered as a multi-class system (in Basque 
language, locative and lative cases in have an animacy-based 
agreement-concordance between nouns and adjectives distinguishing the 
class of animated things against the class of inanimated things), 
otherwise there is an incoherence issue if Swahili is classified as 
having "5 or more" classes while Basque is classified as having less 
than "two" and Russian with only "three" (Russian gender system is based
 on both sex and animacy in a bidimensional relation with a total of six
 classes, while Polish and Czech languages have 4).
Russian language has a 3-gender 4-classes agreement (masculine animate, 
masculine inanimate, feminine, and neuter) in noun-adjective concordance
 (masculine animate, and masculine inanimate, are distinguished in 
singular accusative, while feminine and neuter have distinct conjugation
 patterns for animated and inanimated things, but no concordance 
distinction),
Polish language has a 3-gender 5-classes agreement (virile masculine 
animate, nonvirile masculine animate, masculine inanimate, feminine, and
 neuter) in noun-adjective concordance (masculine animate, and masculine
 inanimate are distinguished in accusative singular, while virile 
masculine animate and non virile masculine animate, are distinguished in
 nominative plural, vocative plural, and accusative plural)
Czech language has a 3-gender 4-classes agreement (masculine animate, 
masculine inanimate, feminine, and neuter) in noun-adjective concordance
 (masculine animate and masculine inanimate, are distinguished in 
singular accusative, plural nominative, and plural vocative),
Basque language has a 1-gender 2-classes agreement (animate, and 
inanimate) in noun-adjective concordance with declinable adjectives 
(animate and inanimate, are distinguished in locative, 
inessive/adessive, allative/illative, terminative, directive, 
destinative, and ablative/elative cases),
Swahili language has a 1-gender 9-classes agreement (m-wa, m-mi, ma, 
ki-vi, n, u, pa, ku, and mu) in noun-adjective agreement with declinable
 adjectives, noun-adjectival/genitive particle, noun-numeral, and other 
noun-determiner concordances and in subject-verb concordance, and a 
1-gender 10-classes (with the addition of person class) in object-verb 
concordance.

post.title: Number of Genders

text:
Russian, and Czech, 
have values "four" for feature 30A, "sex-based" for feature 31A, and 
"semantic and formal" for 32A
Polish has values "five or more" for feature 30A, "sex-based" for 
feature 31A, and "semantic and formal" for 32A
Portuguese, Spanish, French, Italian, Romanian, and Irish (Gaelic), have
 values "two" for feature 30A, "sex-based" for feature 31A, and 
"semantic and formal" for 32A
Danish, and Swedish, have values "two" for feature 30A, "non-sex-based" 
for feature 31A, and "semantic and formal" for 32A
Ecclesiastical Latin, English, Dutch, German, Icelandic, Faroese, 
Norwegian, and Greek, have values "three" for feature 30A, "sex-based" 
for feature 31A, and "semantic and formal" for 32A
Basque has values "two" for feature 30A, "non-sex-based" for feature 
31A, and "semantic and formal" for 32A
Swahili has values "ten" for feature 30A, "non-sex-based" for feature 
31A, and "semantic and formal" for 32A
Vietnamese, Chinese, Korean, and Japanese has values "one" for feature 
30A, "one gender" for feature 31A, and "one gender" for 32A

post.title: Coding of Nominal Plurality

text:
For chapter 35 (I 
cannot comment there) Italian language in third-person has a contrast 
between two series of nominative/ablative/ergative/accusative forms:
lui/lei/egli/ella/loro (with a once-nominal-now-pronominal suffix for 
plural; originally the plurals were elloro in the genitive masculine 
plural and ellaro in the genitive feminine plural, then the form 
"elloro" lost the stem "el-" and the resulting word "loro" replaced both
 genitive feminine plural form and 
nominative/ablative/ergative/accusative forms, meanwhile the accusative 
singular forms "ellui" and "ellei" also dropped the stem "el-" and began
 been used interchangeably with the forms "egli" and "ella"), and
esso/essa/essi/esse (with a nominal suffix for gender and plurality); in
 first- and second-persons the entire stem represents both person and 
plurality (first- and second-person singular pronouns are also the only 
modern Italian words still distinguishing the 
nominative/ablative/ergative case against the accusative case, in the 
second-person by use of a suffix, and in the first-person by use of both
 a suppletive root and the accusative suffix in the accusative).
So the Italian language have to be mapped as with "Person-number stem + 
nominal plural affix".
modern Italian subject personal pronouns
NOM/ABS/ERG.sg.1 "io"	ACC.sg.1 "me"
NOM/ABS/ERG.sg.2 "tu"	ACC.sg.2 "te"
m.sg.3 "lui"/"egli"/"esso"	f.sg.3 "lei"/"ella"/"essa"
pl.1 "noi"
pl.2 "voi"
m.pl.3 "loro"/"essi"	f.pl.3 "loro"/"esse"
"lui/lei/egli/ella/loro" contrapposition may be considered as "person 
stem + archaic nominal gender/number/case affix" (with suppletion)
"esso/essa/essi/esse" contrapposition may be considered as "person stem +
 nominal gender/number affix"
"io" may be considered as "person/number/case stem"
"me/tu/te" may be considered as "person/number stem + case affix"
"noi/voi" contrapposition may be considered as "person stem + archaic 
nominal number affix"
in general this may be mapped as "Person-number stem + nominal plural 
affix"

post.title: Coding of Nominal Plurality

text: The indefinite Article in German is "ein" which is inflected for Case. The Word for "one" is "eins".

post.title: Datapoint German / Indefinite Articles

text:
To reply to Martini 
Pietro: I know the chapter is about politness distinction in 2-nd person
 of personal pronouns, it cannot be otherwise (politness in other person
 pronouns does not exist), if thou had read carefully the question in my
 first comment, thou would have understood that I understood.
As far as I know, in English language when referring to an important 
person (a king, a queen, a pontiff, …) is used the third-person singular
 or plural pronoun with second-person singular polite meaning 
(respectively “His majesty the king”, “Her majesty the queen”, “His 
holiness the pope”, …, instead of “your majesty the king”, “your majesty
 the queen”, “your holiness the pope”, …), this is in contrast to what 
is mapped.
I have always heard greeting people beyond a certain social status by 
using the third person singular or plural instead of the second person 
singular in English speeches.

post.title: Politeness Distinctions in Pronouns

text:
To comment to chapters 
41 to 44 (I cannot comment on them):
In chapter 41 for feature 41A, the Italian language is mapped as having a
 "two-way contrast", however, the Italian language, contrasts between 
"questo" (proximal), "codesto" (medial, also used for near hearer in 
some dialects and contexts), and "quello" (distal), so the Italian 
language for feature 41A have to be mapped as having a "three-way 
contrast".
In chapter 42 for feature 42A, the French language is mapped as having 
"different stem" for pronominal and adnominal demonstratives, however, 
in example (2) is shown French language contrasting adnominal 
demonstratives "ce" and "cette", and pronominal demonstrative "celui" 
and "celle" which evidently share the stem "ce-" and change only the 
suffix, so the French language have to be mapped as having "different 
inflection", not "different stem".
In chapter 43 for feature 43A, the Italian language (currently not 
mapped) may be mapped with value "unrelated".
In chapter 44 for feature 44A, the Italian language is mapped as having 
gender distinction in "3rd person singular only", however, the Italian 
language, has gender distinction also in the 3-rd person plural (gender 
distinction in the 3-rd person plural is optional, not absent) with the 
following gender distinction:
3-rd person personal pronoun form "essi" is dominantly used for:
masculine+masculine=masculine;
3-rd person personal pronoun form "esse" is dominantly used for:
feminine+feminine=feminine;
3-rd person personal pronoun form "loro" (originally the masculine and 
neuter genitive "elloro" contrasted against feminine genitive "ellaro") 
is currently used primarly for:
masculine+feminine=common,
unknown+unknown=unknown,
masculine+unknown=unknown,
feminine+unknown=unknown;
for "essi" is used also non-dominantly for common and unknown, while 
"loro" is used also non-dominantly for masculine and feminine, and 
"esse" has no non-dominant usages;
so the Italian language for feature 44A have to be mapped with gender 
distinction in "3rd person only, but also non-singular".

post.title: Politeness Distinctions in Pronouns

text:
In feature 28A of 
chapter 28 are considered both nominal and pronominal case inflections 
(the same is for feature 50A of chapter 50), while in feature 49A of 
chapter 49 only productive nominal case inflection patterns are 
considered.

post.title: Number of Cases

text:
We have two 
demonstrative articles: dieser/diese/dieses (masculine/feminine/neutral)
 is proximal and jener/jene/jenes is distal, although the latter is 
outdated and rarely used these days. But it's still part of the 
language, so German should be classified as having two-way 
demonstratives. Der/die/das, as given in the examples, are the definite 
articles and can replace either of the demonstratives in informal 
German.

chapter, Pipil is explicitly discussed as an example of a language which
 uses reduplication, but is counted as prefixing on the map, with 
examples such as tukat 'spider' tuhtukat 'spiders.' However, on the map 
itself it has been (erroneously) coded as suffixing.
